What are people using for HIPAA compliant phone/texting systems?
We currently are using Google voice, but definitely are growing out of it and need a more comprehensive and better system. I did a demo with a company called Quo (formerly called open phone) and I was really impressed with them. We have four people that all need to access the phone and we need to keep texts and voice messages organized so things are not getting dropped.

post_text:
Hey everyone, happy Friday! I have had my own clinic (cash and private insurance) for about a year and a half now. I rent space out of a gym and am looking to move to another gym that I align with better. This new gym has a vision of having 5 locations and this is an opportunity to grow with them. I would still rent space out of the gym while being able to use their equipment. The new gym is about 15-20 min drive from my current location.

With that said, has anyone moved from one location to another?

What was your transition plan?

What is the process of changing your address with BCBS and can you have 2 addresses during a transition phase?

I appreciate all your help and insight!

comments.text:
Congratulations! 

We are moving our primary location for a third time in 3 years because we are growing so fast. And now we are also adding a second location too. 

For BCBS, you need to first log into CAQH and add the location. You can have two locations, so just add your new one, leave the old one as your primary location and then the next time you reattest switch the new one to the primary location and delete the old location.

Step 2: log into Availity and go to payer spaces, pick your local Blue Cross, then go to provider enrollment, then choose either individual or group depending on what you are and then select change address and fill out that application. Takes up to 30 days to process
LETS GOOO üí™

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone, happy Friday! I have had my own clinic (cash and private insurance) for about a year and a half now. I rent space out of a gym and am looking to move to another gym that I align with better. This new gym has a vision of having 5 locations and this is an opportunity to grow with them. I would still rent space out of the gym while being able to use their equipment. The new gym is about 15-20 min drive from my current location.

With that said, has anyone moved from one location to another?

What was your transition plan?

What is the process of changing your address with BCBS and can you have 2 addresses during a transition phase?

I appreciate all your help and insight!

COMMENT 1: Congratulations! 

We are moving our primary location for a third time in 3 years because we are growing so fast. And now we are also adding a second location too. 

For BCBS, you need to first log into CAQH and add the location. You can have two locations, so just add your new one, leave the old one as your primary location and then the next time you reattest switch the new one to the primary location and delete the old location.

Step 2: log into Availity and go to payer spaces, pick your local Blue Cross, then go to provider enrollment, then choose either individual or group depending on what you are and then select change address and fill out that application. Takes up to 30 days to process

COMMENT 2: LETS GOOO üí™

I own a mobile PT practice and believe that I‚Äôm ready to expand by adding additional therapists. Is there a ‚Äúcheck-list‚Äù of the steps needed to do this?
Currently a sole proprietor LLC.

comments.text: Just want to help with your wording there. You are a single member LLC not a sole proprietor.  There is a significant difference. Be aware of state and federal laws regarding the difference between a short term contractor and an employee even a PRN one. This is an area where you can face significant penalties if classified incorrectly. Becoming an S Corp is a discussion with your accountant about when this becomes the best option for your overall tax situation

post_text:
How did you all build your referral bases for niche populations? I work mostly in neuro and geriatrics. I've heard mixed things about showing up to doctor's offices. 

Does anyone mind sharing startup costs with creating their LLC and getting started with their business?

comments.text: I made a postcard or flyer type thing and went around to every relevant provider‚Äôs office, including therapy places that don‚Äôt offer my specialty. Some worked out great and I started getting referrals and built relationships with them. Others were very awkward and uncomfortable and I never got any referrals from them. But you have to take the good with the bad. And don‚Äôt try to talk to providers. That makes you look like a menace and a solicitor. Just say that you want to let them know that you are now offering such and such service in the area and you‚Äôd love to be able to help out their patients. Or something like that. Hand them your flyer and leave.

I have my NCS and own a mobile outpatient practice specializing in neurologic conditions (now two full time employees). Happy to share some things that I did for building referrals if you‚Äôd in that population base. Location and healthcare systems in the area may play a factor.

full_thread_text:
POST: How did you all build your referral bases for niche populations? I work mostly in neuro and geriatrics. I've heard mixed things about showing up to doctor's offices. 

Does anyone mind sharing startup costs with creating their LLC and getting started with their business?

COMMENT 1: I made a postcard or flyer type thing and went around to every relevant provider‚Äôs office, including therapy places that don‚Äôt offer my specialty. Some worked out great and I started getting referrals and built relationships with them. Others were very awkward and uncomfortable and I never got any referrals from them. But you have to take the good with the bad. And don‚Äôt try to talk to providers. That makes you look like a menace and a solicitor. Just say that you want to let them know that you are now offering such and such service in the area and you‚Äôd love to be able to help out their patients. Or something like that. Hand them your flyer and leave.

COMMENT 2: I have my NCS and own a mobile outpatient practice specializing in neurologic conditions (now two full time employees). Happy to share some things that I did for building referrals if you‚Äôd in that population base. Location and healthcare systems in the area may play a factor.

post_text: I have a mobile vestibular practice and was wondering who has turned a room or rooms in their home into an office/clinic space and can share the pros and cons and steps needed to do so. When I am officially an empty nester, I will have 2 rooms I can use. One as an office and the other as a gym space. Using my garage is not an option. While I love being mobile and not having rent, I wouldn‚Äôt mind not having to drive all the time. I‚Äôd maybe have 2 days in clinic/home and 2-3 days on the road. Thanks in advance for your input!

comments.text: Hello Shana, I first started my practice out of my home and have since moved it to a separate location. For me, having the business out of the house was great in that I was able to start the biz with minimal overhead and never had to worry about ‚Äúmaking rent.‚Äù It was also convenient to not have to travel. That being said, it was not a longterm fit for me. For one, I was not comfortable with strangers coming to my house which limited my clientele. I also realized I really did not like having clients walking through my house (like you, garage wasn‚Äôt an option). As far as steps needed, I believe that depends on where you live but I had to get a home occupancy permit which was pretty straightforward where I am. Hope this helps and good luck to you!
I did it for a while and would love to go back to it but I have all my mom goodies in it.

post_text:
Hi all,

I‚Äôm trying to get a feel of what can be expected/possible for independant clinicians/practice owners in the NJ area. 

Im still a staff PT, but i‚Äôve been considering starting my own practice in the future. Just want a realistic picture of what that can look like in terms of salary/earnings with overhead costs, insurance, cash pay, etc. 

I understand that it brings freedom and flexibility, but the money is very important to me lol.

Thanks!

Edit:
I currently work in outpatient ortho/sports about 5 years out from PT school. I have my DN cert and am also a Pilates instructor. 

Ideally, I would love to have my own ortho/pilates clinic. But unfortunately for me, all of that equipment is so expensive on top of rent/lease prices in NJ. I am open to the idea of doing mobile visits as well. 

I am late 20s female and do plan on getting married, buying a house, having kids in the next 5 years. So it is all very daunting to think about üò£.

comments.text:
That‚Äôs honestly varies so much based on your target niche and what you want the business to look like.  

We all want and need money to survive and keep the lights on. So obviously that‚Äôs nothing to sniffle at. 

But, many others would agree.  First tell us what your perfect practice looks like. Then reverse engineer it.

post_text:
**OVERVIEW** 
The practice, established over 24 years ago, treats a variety of neurological and orthopedic patients and receives referrals from long standing referral sources and word of mouth.  Practice location Rockaway Park, Queens. The owner is moving out of state.  Patient list  of prior clients and current small caseload ( 25-30 clients daily) can be provided. Office is currently open Monday Wednesday and Friday. The existing phone number is included. This is an ideal opportunity for a therapist looking for an established base upon which to build and grow a practice or for an existing owner looking for a prime second location.
 
**FACILITY AND REAL ESTATE **
The office is over 1500 square foot in a medical building with  a primary care physician and podiatrist in building, and has a private parking lot.  It is ADA compliant. The space is fully equipped, and all clinical and additional equipment is included in the sale; a gym with all equipment, with 10 treatment tables, US, IFC, TENS, LiteCure 15-watt Laser treatment, stools, Anodyne Therapy, 22 feet of Solo Step weight supporting track for gait and balance. Also included is Biodex UBE and Sit2Stand and Shuttle Balance.  Electric traction table for cervical and lumbar traction. There is a  treadmill, an upright bike, 3 NuSteps, hydrocollator, dumbbells, cuff weight, trampoline rebounder, assorted exercise balls, and hand strength equipment.  All equipment is in excellent condition. Original cost of equipment is over $150,000. There is a designated waiting area and front office. Current rent is $4900/month with gas electric and AC included in rent. 
 
**TERMS** 
The practice owner is asking $100,000 and will give favorable terms to any serious buyer who can put 50% down at closing and is able to close in the next 4 months.  For additional information, and to set up a time to see the office, please reach out to the practice owner directly at: trohrs123@yahoo.com

Where is this practice located?

What is the best, fastest and easiest way to change your practice address with all insurances? We recently started our B&M clinic and want to change practice address from my home (used to be my admin office address).

Other than insurances, where should I change the practice address?

comments.text:
In Ohio you need to update your PT license info - change the address of where you are practicing on Ohio OTPTAT 

Check your LLC as well? I think you can update that address.
Update the profiles on CAQH

full_thread_text:
POST: What is the best, fastest and easiest way to change your practice address with all insurances? We recently started our B&M clinic and want to change practice address from my home (used to be my admin office address).

Other than insurances, where should I change the practice address?

COMMENT 1: In Ohio you need to update your PT license info - change the address of where you are practicing on Ohio OTPTAT 

Check your LLC as well? I think you can update that address.

post_text:
I own my own PT practice. I‚Äôm starting to informally teach one on one TMJ/Intraoral/head/face/neck self massage techniques virtually to other providers- PTs, SLPs, and OTs. 

Is the income I generate from that go under my business income? Or do I need to create a new business that is only for the profits I make from course instruction?  

Do I need my students to sign any legal documents?

comments.text: Because the teaching you are doing is not a taxable service, you should be fine operating under your current business entity.  However, for "cleanliness" of it all, create a new LLC for your teaching business.  I would suggest asking your CPA, if you have one.

full_thread_text:
POST: I own my own PT practice. I‚Äôm starting to informally teach one on one TMJ/Intraoral/head/face/neck self massage techniques virtually to other providers- PTs, SLPs, and OTs. 

Is the income I generate from that go under my business income? Or do I need to create a new business that is only for the profits I make from course instruction?  

Do I need my students to sign any legal documents?

COMMENT 1: Because the teaching you are doing is not a taxable service, you should be fine operating under your current business entity.  However, for "cleanliness" of it all, create a new LLC for your teaching business.  I would suggest asking your CPA, if you have one.

post_text:
Hey guys, I'm leaving my job at the hospital. I'm one of the only two specialists here in my field, and I get referrals from the same providers.

I was thinking of emailing them to tell them I'm leaving. Should I mention that I'm starting my own practice so they can refer to me later? There aren't many of us, and I want them to know I'm still around. I'm just worried the hospital might see it as soliciting, you know? I have no clue.

comments.text: I would wait until you are gone and in your new practice. Then reach out to let them know where you are. Most hospitals won‚Äôt want you to tell providers where you are going while you still work there
Just wait until you are at your new practice not before you leave, but make sure that your new practice is very high on the SEObased on your specialty and location

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey guys, I'm leaving my job at the hospital. I'm one of the only two specialists here in my field, and I get referrals from the same providers.

I was thinking of emailing them to tell them I'm leaving. Should I mention that I'm starting my own practice so they can refer to me later? There aren't many of us, and I want them to know I'm still around. I'm just worried the hospital might see it as soliciting, you know? I have no clue.

COMMENT 1: I would wait until you are gone and in your new practice. Then reach out to let them know where you are. Most hospitals won‚Äôt want you to tell providers where you are going while you still work there

COMMENT 2: Just wait until you are at your new practice not before you leave, but make sure that your new practice is very high on the SEObased on your specialty and location

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone here started a small practice in their basement? Thinking mainly for active adults and dry needling

COMMENT 1: You probably need to check zoning and HOA if applicable.

COMMENT 2: Check zoning, HOA, and your home owner's insurance. Some insurances will not cover a home with a home business that serves clients at that location.

OK, are you brainiacs out there? Figure this one out

Wednesday  afternoon

slipped on let‚Äôs just say a banana peel not sure what it was. I did not fall. I did not have any impact. I caught myself and my final position of my leg when I caught myself was foot flat,  knee to about 50 degrees , flexion internal rotation of the hip and adduction of the hip 

For several days, I‚Äôve had super patella swelling , some point tenderness around the fibular head and on the femorsl condyle  anterio-lateral. 

This morning I wake up with bruising on my fibular head , on the lateral tibia proximal  right next to the fibrillar head and on the femoral condo, not on the patella  and a smaller lighter bruise on the medial tibia condyle

I‚Äôve had difficulty with weight-bearing until it gets warmed up and then I have no problem with flexion extension weight-bearing just pivoting. I have no trouble at all doing quad sets since the beginning!

Can go up on left tiptoes no problem

This swelling in half what it was

comments.text:
No pain ascending stairs

Descending discomfort at full flexion..likely swelling

I am now 48 hours past injury and the only symptom I‚Äôm having is discomfort in the femoral head 
where the bruise is so I‚Äôm beginning to think that I have a tear in ant-superior 
Tibiofibular ligament which interestingly enough is where the most bruising is even though it‚Äôs already discolored and Brown, after only 40 hours

Still some supra patellar swelling, but it‚Äôs going down significantly every day and quad contraction of any kind doesn‚Äôt set off any symptom

post_text:
Had a meeting with a large primary care practice (over 3,000 patients). They had a PT clinic in these 2 rooms for over 5 years and that practice led to open their own space elsewhere. They want me to sublease the space (the price seems quite high to me at $2k/month for these 2 teeny rooms). 

My thought is to offer a PT being on site 1 afternoon per week to see referrals as walk ins for screens and could schedule follow up's for that time at a fraction of that rent or maybe a % of revenue. 

I have owned my practice for over 10 years and am 75% mobile and have another much larger brick and mortar clinic on the other side of town at which I see patients 2 days per week. 

I love the idea of getting into primary care but not sure this is a good fit. Thoughts?

comments.text: I have 5 rooms in my office and the rent is $4350/month I live in Fort Worth Tx. The goal is to hire MT to work with me. But while I'm building my business I have other people renting the other offices (laser hair removal, Functional Med Nurse practiciner, esthetician, infrared sauna room, and bodywork) one day a week I have some one renting my office too. What I don't have is 3000 potential clients walking past my office.  That seems like a deal to me.  What are the lease terms? Could you split the lease with another PT that is specialized in something different than you, like Pelvic Floor PT. That way your not fighting over the same type of clients and or hire a PT PRN.  At the end of the day you want to enjoy the space your in and it to be functional.

post_text: Just starting my cash based business. I gave a patient my superbill with my EIN. She submitted to UHC and they're requesting a TIN not an EIN. comments.text: I‚Äôm thinking the insurance company is mistaken, if you have an EIN. All claims for my business for 5 years have only ever used the business EIN, as we had applied for that.
As I understand it, there are several kinds of TINs (Tax ID Number), including your SSN (social security number) and EIN. Therefore, your EIN *is* your TIN.

post_text: Probably will have mixed responses on this but wanted to pose the question. What have people seen with NDAs/non competes. Do they tend to hold up upon leaving a clinic? For reasons I don‚Äôt want to disclose, this isnt a good place for me to stay. Buried in our handbook was a NDA that was never discussed. The verbiage states I can‚Äôt work physical therapy in general within a certain mile radius that would essentially prevent me from working at all. It seems overly broad.

comments.text:
It really depends on the location I‚Äôve won them before as the owner as long as it‚Äôs reasonable. It also can‚Äôt ‚Äúcause undue hardship‚Äù which may be up to a judge to interpret. Be careful of any no solicitation agreements as well. 

If I were you I‚Äôd put the whole thing into chatgpt and ask it how you should proceed

My understanding is if a patient follows you, that is their business. But if you TELL the patient to follow you, or "call up" your old patients after you left, it would be against the NC clause, and also unethical. That being said- patients I personally BROUGHT to a clinic are still MINE if I leave that clinic.

full_thread_text:

post_text:
Hello, everyone! 
Looking for help! 

DPT and first time mom here! I‚Äôm in the middle of my maternity leave and the idea of having to go back to work and leave my baby girl is daunting! I‚Äôve always toyed with the idea of starting a mobile cash-based practice but chicken out everytime! I took a Herman & Wallace Pelvic Health course last summer and never got to use anything I learned. I‚Äôm seriously considering attempting to get something mobile started now and would like my focus to be on pregnant and postpartum mothers. I haven‚Äôt taken any classes on pregnancy but would love to. I‚Äôm not able to do this fill time but could start slow and see where it takes me. What is the reality that something like this could work? Mobile cash-based pregnant/postpartum patients. Any insight is more than welcome. Can anyone weigh in on this? I‚Äôm so over working for other people and would love to give my girl all of the attention she needs! Thank you!!!

comments.text:
I‚Äôd say this is definitely doable but don‚Äôt just fall for the fantasy of how great it sounds. It CAN be, but after a lot of work, even if you plan to start slowly. There will be a lot of work to go into starting a business you won‚Äôt know about til you start, even slow/part time. I did this coming back from my first mat leave and I have no regrets, but wish someone painted a realistic picture for me. It was way more work and is now the flexible venture I wanted. The end goal of working part time and being with my kiddo was possible, but the work to get it going wasn‚Äôt as simple or ‚Äúpart time‚Äù as I thought. I would much rather work hard for myself than someone else, but just want you to have a realistic view of what it entails. 

I also think you‚Äôll need to take more coursework to adequately treat this population as a solo provider without mentorship. 

I‚Äôd also recommend the Business Accelerator course through Pelvic PT Rising. It‚Äôs an investment that will save you a lot of headaches and mistakes as you launch!
Definitely doable but don‚Äôt get confused, it‚Äôs not ‚Äúless work‚Äù or less time.

I work part time for someone else while building my llc further. I never mention my llc (my boss knows i have it and supports me fully, but i never ever mention to any of my part time job patients that i even have an llc. I keep it totally separate) 
Someone i treated approx 6 months ago at the part time job mustve googled me- found me on linked in and then also my fb page for my llc. She messaged me saying she wants to see me 1 on 1 with my llc. I usually just say no, because I feel bad that it was a patient from my part time job. I dont want any blurry lines. But she did reach out on her own. What do i do? Im usually a play it safe person

comments.text: Personally I would recommend just asking your part time boss about their thoughts.  It sounds like you have a positive relationship and open dialogue already established.

post_text: So, i have an interested client whom knows others interested in mobile cash  PT. Help me calculate my start up "Leg Work time". If I get my PLLC vs LLC ( have to contact my county today), how many days do y'all think I'll be ready to start treating? I still have to buy a laptop and Jane, and liability insurance. But those are quick to do. ; ) i have K tape, Edge iastm tool, foam roll, and occipivot, and foldable tx table. Am.starting slow, 1 day a wk txs. Still working my job. 4d/ wk

comments.text: That makes sense.  Thanks

You can start treating the moment you have your liability insurance after establising your business. In some cases you can function as a sole proprietor (I personally recommend a separate entity even if you will be a single member). You don‚Äôt need a fancy EMR. You can do hand written notes or a word document to just start off.

Looking for some advice. For those of you who started a side hustle while working FT and then transitioned to your business FT‚Ä¶ At what point did you drop the full time job? 

I‚Äôve been seeing 12-15 patients a week on my own while also working 35-40 hrs at my full time gig and I feel like I‚Äôm barely treading water. üòÖ 

I‚Äôm afraid to quit because of losing my insurance, and the fear of just relying on my business as income. Any guidance is appreciated. üôÇ

post_text:
Have a PT who is pregnant and is going to be taking maternity leave.

She doesn‚Äôt qualify for FMLA as she just started working 5 months ago. But we do have paid maternity leaveve

My question: we offer 6 weeks of maternity leave that‚Äôs paid. How do I go about asking her how long she plans on taking off? Like if she wanted to take more after those 6 weeks. Just so we have a start back date that we can transition her patients back to her. Do we go ahead and set that now?

comments.text:
YES - talk now. Just know that plans may change. But, have an idea in your head of how things may/may not play out. 

Talk with her, as if she was your own daughter, sister, wife, friend, etc. 

In my past personal experiences working for someone else, the more they treated me like a human, with kindness and understanding, the more I respected and desired to please my employer. 

It‚Äôs sad, but most leaders don‚Äôt get this. Men, in particular. 

Demonstrating kindness, empathy, or compassion when communicating is not a sign of weakness. **You can be a strong leader while still being kind.

Obviously, when an employee takes advantage of the employer‚Äôs kindness or empathy, that is an issue. The employer must take action to ensure it doesn‚Äôt happen more than once. 

Giving each employee the benefit of the doubt, in the beginning, is the best approach, in my opinion. 

Be direct and honest with her about YOUR needs as an employer/business owner, while simultaneously demonstrating understanding for her situation. 

Any reasonable person understands you need to ensure you have a physical PT in the clinic to treat clients until she returns. 

Let us know how the talk goes - interested to hear how it plays out!

First things first‚Ä¶ way to go offering some paid maternity leave. That is a huge blessing for families! 

Secondly, I‚Äôd just request a meeting and chat about it! Then recheck in at the 6 week mark in case she changes her mind so you have time to adapt.

post_text: Michigan PTs/OTs‚ÄîI‚Äôve started a cash-based home safety & modification business and am finalizing details before officially launching. I know we can recommend and set up adaptive equipment (e.g., shower chairs) but likely can‚Äôt install structural modifications (e.g., grab bars). Where is the legal line drawn for what we can/can‚Äôt install ourselves? Also, what are some modifications we can legally provide that might surprise us or that we may not have considered? Any insight would be greatly appreciated!

comments.text: What area do you serve?

You need to be very familiar with the Stark anti-kickback laws. You also need to be very clear on " Medically Necessary and Skilled" definitions. AOTA has a great delineation between three types, evaluations of older clients and which can be billed and which cannot be billed

post_text: Are there return to golf criteria like there are return to sport for acl pts. I have a pt who had a meniscectomy 2 months ago n wants to golf in 2 weeks. I plan in isokinetix testing quads/hams. Imo it seems too soon but hes an active college guy n tolerating walking an hour aerobically

comments.text:
2 months out of menisectomy he should be fine to return. 

I would have him slowly ramp up over the next 2 weeks starting with wedge shots and working down his bag as each day passes. 

We want to make sure he has appropriate hip mobility and ankle mobility to help take the stress of his knee. 

If he has full ROM, close to full strength and zero pain scores, let him send it.

full_thread_text:
POST: Are there return to golf criteria like there are return to sport for acl pts. I have a pt who had a meniscectomy 2 months ago n wants to golf in 2 weeks. I plan in isokinetix testing quads/hams. Imo it seems too soon but hes an active college guy n tolerating walking an hour aerobically

COMMENT 1: 2 months out of menisectomy he should be fine to return. 

I would have him slowly ramp up over the next 2 weeks starting with wedge shots and working down his bag as each day passes. 

We want to make sure he has appropriate hip mobility and ankle mobility to help take the stress of his knee. 

If he has full ROM, close to full strength and zero pain scores, let him send it.

post_text: When I opened my clinic I was an LLC. I've been busy enough that we were able to transition to an SCorp. The gal at Noridian tells me that I have to fill out a brand new application to change my status with Medicare which is not what I was told initially. Does that sound right? My CPA has done everything with the IRS. Thanks for your feedback

comments.text: You have to fill out an election form to be taxed as Scorp. You do not have to re-enroll with Medicare.
You will have to fill out and submit a form declaring your tax status as a S-Corp. this is different than an application for an LLC.

full_thread_text:
POST: When I opened my clinic I was an LLC. I've been busy enough that we were able to transition to an SCorp. The gal at Noridian tells me that I have to fill out a brand new application to change my status with Medicare which is not what I was told initially. Does that sound right? My CPA has done everything with the IRS. Thanks for your feedback

COMMENT 1: You have to fill out an election form to be taxed as Scorp. You do not have to re-enroll with Medicare.

COMMENT 2: You will have to fill out and submit a form declaring your tax status as a S-Corp. this is different than an application for an LLC.

**AW RITE! AW RITE! AW RITE!**

It's the start of *Holiday Week Eve*!

Time to **KICK IT UP A NOTCH!** üï∫üïé‚úùÔ∏è

Kicking it up at his practice by looking to hire is Stephen Dunn! If you are in the Austin, TX area, or want to move there, give my dude a holler!

The hardest working man I know, Jeremy Sutton, upped his Famousity by talking about his initiative, *Senior Day*, on KSLA News 12 in the Shreveport - Bossier City area!

post_text:
I posted this earlier but got no response so I‚Äôm reposting for assistance. 

I started my mobile therapy practice in Florida and saw some patients but now I can‚Äôt continue due to work-related injury and an auto collision injury.  How do I dissolve my LLC, stop my subscription with my EMR, should I close my business bank account?

comments.text:
Sorry you're going through that!
To answer your Qs....
1. Most states have a simple one page form to dissolve a LLC on their secretary of state website. I'd do that and file it before the end of the year to avoid taxes or annual fees for the following year.
2. Email your EMR company and tell them what you want to do
3. No need to close your business checking right away and personally I would probably wait until after you do your taxes
Do you plan to return to work?

full_thread_text:
POST: I posted this earlier but got no response so I‚Äôm reposting for assistance. 

I started my mobile therapy practice in Florida and saw some patients but now I can‚Äôt continue due to work-related injury and an auto collision injury.  How do I dissolve my LLC, stop my subscription with my EMR, should I close my business bank account?

COMMENT 1: Sorry you're going through that!
To answer your Qs....
1. Most states have a simple one page form to dissolve a LLC on their secretary of state website. I'd do that and file it before the end of the year to avoid taxes or annual fees for the following year.
2. Email your EMR company and tell them what you want to do
3. No need to close your business checking right away and personally I would probably wait until after you do your taxes

COMMENT 2: Do you plan to return to work?

post_text:
A while back I went through the process of getting my LLC to begin my own mobile OT business.  Life got in the way then and I ended up moving 4 hours away (back to my home town).  After the move, I never regained the momentum to keep pressing on with the business idea.  

Now I find myself facing a (mostly ethical) dilemma.  I live close to my parents and both of them are declining in health in different ways.  But they are also both in need of hospital beds.  Can I, ethically and legally, use my license and (so far unused) business to become their OT in order to write the required letters of medical necessity to help them get the equipment they need?

I have permission to give medical background if needed.

comments.text: I‚Äôve worked on my parents before PT mobile. I documented their issues like I would with anyone and documented their treatments. There shouldn‚Äôt be any problem with that

Write the letter and talk with their physician for signature. 
Disclose your relationship to the physician.

full_thread_text:
POST: A while back I went through the process of getting my LLC to begin my own mobile OT business.  Life got in the way then and I ended up moving 4 hours away (back to my home town).  After the move, I never regained the momentum to keep pressing on with the business idea.  

Now I find myself facing a (mostly ethical) dilemma.  I live close to my parents and both of them are declining in health in different ways.  But they are also both in need of hospital beds.  Can I, ethically and legally, use my license and (so far unused) business to become their OT in order to write the required letters of medical necessity to help them get the equipment they need?

I have permission to give medical background if needed.

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôve worked on my parents before PT mobile. I documented their issues like I would with anyone and documented their treatments. There shouldn‚Äôt be any problem with that

COMMENT 2: Write the letter and talk with their physician for signature. 
Disclose your relationship to the physician.

post_text: Hello beautiful people! I Have a question, I‚Äôm trying to get a POC signed for a Medicare patient and it says in the script start date : 10/23/24 end date 4/23/25. Does that mean once the POC is signed, it‚Äôs good for 6 months?

comments.text: The script is valid for 6months - meaning you can evaluate and/or initialize a POC within that window of time. Your POC is an entirely separate thing. You ask for what you anticipate needing within whatever length of time you determine it will take for you to meet the goals you establish.
A signed POC is required by MC, not a script. A POC can be good for up to 90 days, but you need to get an updated POC signed if you go beyond that. Below is a quick reference.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello beautiful people! I Have a question, I‚Äôm trying to get a POC signed for a Medicare patient and it says in the script start date : 10/23/24 end date 4/23/25. Does that mean once the POC is signed, it‚Äôs good for 6 months?

COMMENT 1: The script is valid for 6months - meaning you can evaluate and/or initialize a POC within that window of time. Your POC is an entirely separate thing. You ask for what you anticipate needing within whatever length of time you determine it will take for you to meet the goals you establish.

COMMENT 2: A signed POC is required by MC, not a script. A POC can be good for up to 90 days, but you need to get an updated POC signed if you go beyond that. Below is a quick reference.

post_text: Anyone here start a running club? I'd be interested learning about it. TIA

comments.text:
I work almost exclusively with runners and am part of a few run clubs. If you take the time to grow it slowly as an inclusive group for all levels it will flourish and you can promote yourself through it and offer services. I would strongly discourage charging any fees from the beginning just to be part of a group. 
If you have a local running shop I would start there for logistics or planning.
Yes. Mine is very low key. I can give you some tips though. I‚Äôve been in quite a few clubs too and can tell you what not to do üòÜ

I‚Äôve had a side business as a sole proprietorship for a few years. At this time I have a college who would like to start participating in the clinic and would like to become a partner. 

What are your guys experience with this? Would you recommend a partnership? Or should I bring them on as a independent contractor 

There is a piece of equipment that we both want (3D running gait analysis) and they are willing to pay half, hence the potential partnership. I can afford the full cost myself but it stretches the budget thin

Any advice would be great! Thanks!

comments.text: I have a business partner and love it. But we started the business together and worked together prior to that. I don‚Äôt think buying a piece of expensive equipment together is a reason to start a partnership. If you have other reasons besides that, then it could be a good decision, but I don‚Äôt think purchasing a piece of equipment is reason enough. Ôøº
I wouldn‚Äôt do any partnerships. Contract him out as a 1099.

post_text:
Not having the bad doesn't make you good... 

I've had several times over the past couple weeks where I've been on calls with people interested in starting a business and they say something to the effect of, "I just want to get away from the crappy way healthcare is run." 

I get it. I've been there and have had some really bad experiences in healthcare and in jobs in the past. 

But just moving away from the bad and not being like them only goes so far. 

Each time I've asked, "what do you want your business to look like, what's the GOOD you're going to bring?" and each time the person couldn't answer it. 

Absolutely move away from the bad in healthcare but don't start there. Fill your business with things that are inspiring, hope providing, excellent, client focused, etc.

comments.text:
THIS! üôåüíØ

Revitalizing healthCARE is more than NOT being what everybody else is üí™
Be the change!

It's FRIDAY!! 

You know what that means, people. 

Time to **KICK IT UP A NOTCH!**

Excited for my dude, Steven Baptiste.  His clinic, *Elev8 Movement LLC*, was nominated for *Best of Gwinnett County* (Atlanta, GA)! LET'S GOOOOO!! 

Kicking It Up BIG TIME tomorrow will be Ashley Will.  She is getting married in beautiful Sedona, AZ! CONGRATS!! 

Crystal Abitz dropped some big news this week.  She announced that the family will be growing to a party of 5 in the Spring! WOO! HOO! 

Jeremy Sutton is making strides in his practice, Healthy SBC  (Shreveport - Bossier City, LA)  He has announced that he soon will be adding a location to compliment the mobile aspect! GROWING, BROTHER!!! 

One way to grow Famousity is to appear in the local magazine.  That's exactly what Josh Lopez did this week. His spread (and mug shot) on *Should Getting Stiffer As We Age Really Be Considered Normal?* appeared in the *Active Senior Living of Mohave County* (AZ)!! 

Bill Johnson has grown his practice to 2 therapists now after only 13 months in business! But he's not done.  A third will be starting soon! UNCAGED!!!! 

Perhaps the grandest way to KICK IT UP is to bring life into the world. BIG CONGRATS to Meagan Duncan and hubby Jason who welcomed their newest bundle of joy, little Cael Phillip! 

Wedding Bliss abounds! CONGRATS to April Manint Egan who got married!!!

Shout Out to Kevin Hamidi who spoke at the 6th IFCA Legacy retreat! SOLID, bro!!

Tricia Smith said "ADIOS" today to the job in WI.  She is headed back home to Ohio!! CHEERS!! 

Jordan Floyd had the Grand Opening for his newest location of *Limitless Therapy and Wellness*. This one in Spartanburg, SC! LOVE THE GROWTH, my friend!! 

I am beyond stoked for Kelly Shannon, the personal physical therapist for women's professional tennis player, Emma Navarro, currently ranked #10 in the world.  Navarro made it to the semi-finals of the women's US OPEN - her first major semi-final! Although she lost, it was an incredible leap in her journey. WAY TO HAVE HER IN TIP TOP SHAPE, KELLY!! 

We ain't done with the US Open! Wolfgang Oswald, personal PT for men's #12 player, Taylor Fritz, has his player playing in his first Major semi-final as well!  LET'S GOOO! 

Selfishly, I gotta give a shout out to my "Black Sheep" classmates from Shenandoah Univ Class of '94 who are gathered for our 30th Reunion!  I wish I was there with you all!! Kelly Crispell, Eric Schneider, Steve Patane, Bill Johnson, Karen R. Jones, and many others!! MISS YOU GUYS!!  I wanna hear you belt it out to *FRIENDS IN LOW PLACES *!!

EVERYBODY, make it a FANTAWESOME weekend!

comments.text: You were definitely missed!!
Appreciate you David!! ü§ù

Any recommendations for older client with PD who freezes during golf/tennis and difficulty with walking backwards. Recent decline with 10 yr history PD. Will be starting meds for first time soon.
Music/metronome seems to help with BW walking. Doing BIG daily. Says he‚Äôs okay on range but not when on the course/when he‚Äôs trying to take peoples monies.

comments.text:
Hey Andrew, I‚Äôd concur with what Evie and Kaitlin said already, but would add that maybe he should look into a tune up for LSVT BIG with a therapist, as he could make more gains and it can be done as many times as needed. PWR! Is certainly versatile and could be great too and may be more engaging as something to do in addition to or in substitute or LSVT. 

I‚Äôve been LSVT certified since 2013 and have seen it work wonders. We address freezing of gait a LOT with this method.

I‚Äôm simply impressed that he‚Äôs had a 10 year history and still playing and just starting meds!  Wow . (In addition to Boxing for PD - which I love for RAM )  

See if there‚Äôs  a treadmill available, can he practice walking backwards using the railing and then having the therapist stop/ start and change incline to keep that motion going in a controlled environment. I know that doesn‚Äôt transfer to playing, but it‚Äôs a good skill to have Ôøº

POST: Just getting started with my mobile PT practice. What are some equipment items you bring with you? Any tips or advice you have for someone just starting out? I‚Äôve been a clinician for 10+ years, but ready for this change.

COMMENT 1: I use a backpack with packing cubes with Theraband, ktape, Gua sha tools, freeup, goniometers, stretch out strap, gloves, dry needling supplies, pulse ox and wrist BP. I keep an adjustable kettle bell, foam balance, cones and a rocker board in my car as needed

post_text: Motivating post‚Ä¶ Was contacted by patient‚Äôs family member who is looking to hire a private practice PT. After talking with her, it became apparent she actually was never taught foundational knowledge of caring from a functional mobility standpoint (She had an extensive exercise packet that included ankle pumps, though). They owned equipment, hired caregivers, had two other family members and patient was being seen by home health intermittently previously. When I went over and met them, I was able to teach them how to do a two person transfer of the patient safely with a slide board from the hospital bed to their custom wheelchair. First time up in it in a year. It opened the world to them to know that they would be able to take her outside, tilt her back or do her hair, and it was really more about their piece of mine as well as the parent. In case you need to know why it‚Äôs so important that you all open good common sense, clinical practices, this is why! If there is anyone in the Fremont California area available to take on a lower level patient, DM me.

post_text: I have owned my own LLC since February and am currently still working part time at an OP clinic. At the OP clinic, we do not have a receptionist and it falls on the therapists to answer phones, schedule patients, do patient intake, open up the clinic, etc. Since opening my own business and reducing my hours, my boss has been criticizing me for clocking in 10-15 minutes early to do the tasks above. My thinking is that this is the cost of not having a receptionist and I can‚Äôt be expected to do these tasks for free. Any insight would be appreciated!

comments.text: I think your boss needs to consider who is supposed to be paid to open the clinic 15 min early so clients dont' arrive to a locked door. If they want someone else to do it they can schedule them and let you know that you shouldn't. If they want you to do it, you can't legally work off the clock.

I totally agree you should be paid for those extra tasks. I would have a convo with the boss and say you wouldn‚Äôt mind helping out but will be paid for that time or else you will be arriving right as the session starts and leaving we soon as it is over.

full_thread_text:

My thinking is that this is the cost of not having a receptionist and I can‚Äôt be expected to do these tasks for free. Any insight would be appreciated!

COMMENT 1: I think your boss needs to consider who is supposed to be paid to open the clinic 15 min early so clients dont' arrive to a locked door. If they want someone else to do it they can schedule them and let you know that you shouldn't. If they want you to do it, you can't legally work off the clock.

COMMENT 2: I totally agree you should be paid for those extra tasks. I would have a convo with the boss and say you wouldn‚Äôt mind helping out but will be paid for that time or else you will be arriving right as the session starts and leaving we soon as it is over.

post_text:
So I am supposed to start my new job at a brand new facility soon. Was supposed to be July 8 th but town is giving us a hard time about zoning issue all of a sudden. I was called to meet with manager today about something. That something was they were approached to take over another practice that the chiropractor owner was leaving. He saw the coming soon sign on building and called to ask if wanted to take over lease and a PT was willing to stay. So now I am supposed to do hours their and market for new place. I have reservations about them taking over lease. They basically want to make it their second practice. They want to use same EMR  etc. haven‚Äôt seen place yet 
Just not sure if good idea

comments.text: what is the benefit to your business? I can understand the Chiropractor looking for relief from his lease but you already have a plan in place. Unless you feel the zoning issues will be unresolvable, starting two practices at the same time is a lot. What reputation does the other office have? Plus do you want to inherit the PT? Remember your business plan to avoid going off on tangents that will not keep you on the track you laid out for business.

I‚Äôm completely confused to be honest. Are you an employee or are you going into business with these people you took a job with? as an employee, I wouldn‚Äôt think you would care what they‚Äôre doing to grow their business other than to make sure that what you were promised is delivered ‚Äì in other words you wanted to work at one facility at a certain location and if they‚Äôre trying to change that then that‚Äôs a different story. Perhaps you can clarify.

post_text: My current job is perfect on paper, I really have no reason for leaving other than my dream for many years has been to open a pediatric clinic in my town. A space opened up right next to our pediatricians office and I can‚Äôt get it off my mind. It‚Äôs expensive for where I‚Äôm at in my private practice - just started mobile on the side of my full time. How do you make the decision on whether or not to take a HUGE leap of faith or play the safe route and build up my practice more before going all in?? Anyone have a similar experience either good or bad‚Ä¶?

comments.text:
That‚Äôs so tough! And I know it looks so different for everyone as each families financial situation is different. 

Personally I was able to find a fitness studio to rent from during the day and it has been amazing for getting started. I have only worked part time for the last 3 years so we weren‚Äôt financially counting on a full time salary, but starting out sharing space with a studio has given me so much peace of mind. It‚Äôs allowed me to be profitable from the beginning (even though it may have been minimal per patient to start). But the ability to open without losing money for the first few months has been so nice. I opened in November, have saved up enough in the business to cover me if I was suddenly off for 6 months and have taken home a solid paycheck the last two months. But I really attribute it largely to having rent that has been less than $500/month. I could have easily been paying $1600 a month and lost money in most of my early months.

I have the same dream- to open a pediatric PT clinic and there's a need in our town. Its a hard decision and only you can answer your question.  Ask yourself why do you want to do it. When you get that clarity then you will be lead to the right path...then you'll know which step to take. Uncaged has helped me in this process.
My business is 1.5 yrs old. I started mobile while still working PRN for 6 months then went full time mobile. 
Best of luck to you and God bless!

post_text:
I am currently a Medicare/ cash mobile PT in Florida.  I have been growing for the last few years, but exploded this January when I started to take Medicare (even though that is only about 30-40% of my business).  

I have a PTA starting in July, and will ramp up my marketing in the next week or so to get her schedule filled. So far my growth has been word of mouth.  

I have found a brick and mortar that is near our small town‚Äôs downtown, and I have fallen in love with the space. But, I have no idea where I would start to figure out if I can make it happen financially, and fill it.

How do I go about projecting numbers/ financials for a new hire and a space.  Also, things like.. is it a good size, a good price (i have looked at other listings nearby and it is comparable)? Is there a way to objectively figure out if it will be profitable enough to incur this new overhead and possible headahces associated with leasing?

Also is there a magic formula to determine when I am able to ‚Äúafford it.‚Äù.  I.E. 3-6 month emergency fund (dave ramsey style), have a wait list, have a certain % in savings, etc. 

Thanks so much.  I am super comfortable with being mobile, and it is working very well. However, I am a dreamer and this space has me thinking of ALL the possibilities for growth.

comments.text: Cautionary tale here. I overestimated how many non insured or OON clients I would have and have ended up with 95% Medicare. I am not even close to covering all of my expenses and am now trying to break my lease after only 2 of 5 committed years w/o declaring bankruptcy so I can shift to a less expensive location. Covid really changed building occupancy. I was told my building was 95% leased. The building is practically empty because entire floors are empty. I don‚Äôt get the young professionals in I was anticipating. Construction started across 2 streets and took all of the parking I thought I would have. I should have fought harder for a true break lease clause.

You really just have to run the numbers. Come up with your average reimbursement per visit (and I always low ball this). Come up with what your expenses will be once you hire (and I always overestimate this). You can also underestimate how many visits you and the PTA will have total per week. If the numbers still work, then you‚Äôre good.

post_text: So I interviewed for a position at a facility that will be opening in June.  This was back in February. It is a business man who son is in PT school and wanted to start a practice for him. They wanted a therapist to help get practice going as well as cont to work. As they were going through the process they told me in order to open it on time the practice needed to be owned by a PT in NJ. So they said if I wanted to they could put my name on the LLC and transfer it to the son once he passes his boards. We are still waiting for attorney to do all the paperwork work but wanted some idea if this was an issue. I‚Äôll be paid salary vs 1099   We have an EMR amd equipment. Need to start marketing to physicians in area. As of now not a lot of PT places in area. It‚Äôs will be Medicare amd OON only. Any specific questions I should be asking g or looking for in this paper work

comments.text: why are yall worried about lawsuits ??

If you own it. You have the liability.  
In order for you to sell it to him money should likely exchange hands of sorts. 

After all they are truly renting your license and you should see it as such. 
If not a sale I would be asking for an ownership portion and get some of that equity. 

Many business people focus on profits and not patient care etc.  be mindful of that. 

This father likely sees $$$ 

Either way you need a good exit package plan in place.  

If it‚Äôs a no from them it should also be a no from you.

post_text:
Seeking advice/suggestions. I opened an LLC a few years ago, but have not been actively seeing clients due to working full time elsewhere. I still upkeep the business license, web domain, etc. 

My spouse got a new job and we are relocating to another state. I would like to start seeing my own clients again, instead of working for another company. The new state requires a PLLC. Are you allowed to open a PLLC with the same name? Should I start another business with a different name? I plan on keeping my therapy license in both states, so could see clients virtually with my old LLC. 

Has anyone ever encountered this situation, or have advice? Thank you!!

comments.text: The name will be irrelevant for a new state because it's a different state, unless someone else has already taken that name, then you're fine. However, I would keep all your clients under one LLC not two. You can still see clients in the old state with your new state llc. All that matters is you are professionally licensed in the states that you are seeing them.

The name likely won‚Äôt be an issue if it‚Äôs not already registered/taken. Your answer depends on how much you think you‚Äôll net in the PLLC. If above 40K, and the first LLC was set up as a Solo prop,  you should set the second one up as an S corp. if the first was an LLC/ S corp, I‚Äôd put the PLLC under the S corp.

post_text:
Hello,
I have a young LLC that has an EIN, Type 2 NPI, and is enrolled with Medicare / Novitas. 
I had a change of heart and would like to change the name of the LLC. I've heard that doing a DBA might be easier, however I have no marketing, branding, commercial insurance contracts at this point and only have one patient, so I figure this is the time to formally change the name.

Does any one have experience with changing the name of their LLC (not DBA)? As far as I know I need to file an ammendment with the state (NJ), the IRS, and update PECOS, NPPES, and CAQH. 

I believe the EIN stays the same but do I need a new Type 2 NPI as well? Does the name change affect any pending claims with Medicare? 

Thanks for your help!

comments.text:
I rebranded in the winter and in Minnesota I initially considered doing a DBA but at the state level (at least) a DBA filing doesn‚Äôt  protect your business name from another person using it (so someone else could come along and file a LLC which is protected with your DBA and you‚Äôd have no rights to fight them on this).  I didn‚Äôt find the process all that terrible.  It‚Äôs like changing your last name with marriage.  Lots of companies to contact but not the end of the world

I‚Äôm not in network with any insurances so I can‚Äôt speak to that but to update a business name change with the IRS I just had to write a letter and it was processed on their end in a few weeks.  The instructions are online, I found it to be very straight forward.  I believe the process can be longer if you are changing from a LLC to say a S-corp due to change in tax structure
Get a new EIN and start over vs the 1yr + to complete a proper name change w the IRS

For those who opened a physical location. 
I just signed a lease with my landlord, he‚Äôs asking for financial statements, I‚Äôm a start up business so I don‚Äôt know what is expected as far financial statements. Can someone shed some light? I asked my accountant and he said ‚Äúyou wouldn‚Äôt have P/L because you haven‚Äôt started operating‚Äù .

comments.text: This is very common and seems standard practice. They want to determine if you have the ability to personally guarantee the lease. Was part of the terms of the lease in writing that you provided financial statements?  I wouldn‚Äôt think he needs to see your financial statements especially if it‚Äôs something that he‚Äôs just added on that he wants after you signed.

post_text: I am looking for advice on how to balance this. I started my busines, I have 3 clients currently but seeing them in home. I just signed my lease for my clinic with a move in date beginning of June. My current full time job is now switching from a 3 day work week to 4 days. So during those 4 days I won‚Äôt be able to focus on my business. Will working 1 week day and possibly both weekend days be feasible to build a full caseload? This is for a ped clinic.

comments.text: I think you can definitely build your caseload with one weekday and two weekend days. I think that would work well. Then, once those days are full, that‚Äôs when you quit your other job. Hopefully you‚Äôll be making enough money at your business at that point, where you won‚Äôt need the other job to support yourself and you can then further build your caseload. When you talk to new patients, just tell them ‚Äúthis is when I have openings‚Äù. You don‚Äôt need to tell them that you work somewhere else on other days.

Any possibility of you going part time? Honestly I was working FT when I started my biz and didn't focus and give as much attention as I had a safety net with my FT job. Then went part time but still not focusing on myself. Everyone is different with different drive so if you want to eventually do your own biz, try to see if you can request the part time or keeping 3 days. I am more driven now to success as my income is my own biz and not other jobs so doing more work/networking.

post_text:
I‚Äôve recently been seeing friend suggestions for patients of mine on my personal (and fairly well disguised) Facebook page.  Obviously I‚Äôm not adding them as friends, but I don‚Äôt like this! And are they being suggested to see me? I hope not! How can I stop it?

I suspect this is because I manage my business fb page and maybe also because my biz email address is linked in to the biz account and Facebook is seeing who I‚Äôve emailed?

Don‚Äôt want to be a conspiracy theorist or break hippa or have my privacy compromised.

Advice?!

comments.text: It's based on location I think. Turn location service off. Their phone picks up yours and links the 2 of you are possible friends. Creepy the lines they cross really.

Also if you have their phone number or have reached out to them via personal cell phone that is logged into FB. I personally block them as soon as I see it as a suggested. My block list is a very very long list haha

post_text:
Hoping someone here has some advice!
Short story is a scammer opened a business checking account using my LLC and EIN. I found out because the bank sent a monthly statement and then a change of address letter.  I was able to shut it down (hopefully) before any damage was caused but I'm not sure it ends here. The fraud department at USBank said scammers will typically open multiple bank accounts at the same time with the stolen info. So my question is, how can I pull a "business credit" report to see if someone has opened lines of credit or other checking accounts in my business name?  Nothing is showing on my personal credit report but neither is the legit business LOC that I have with my bank so I'm not sure if would even appear there. 
TIA for any insight

comments.text: Did you notify the credit bureaus so they can freeze your account from new credit allowances? Trans Union, Equifax and ??? ( The third one is escaping me at the moment)
You can also pull one free credit report from each bureau once a year. That'll allow you to verify your accounts and see others if they are on there.

post_text:
Change of condition report for DME. How does everyone else do them? 

This is to inform the insurance provider of a change in the patient's condition. Following a successful joint replacement in 2021, the patient has now experienced a change in health due to a CVA. The current standard rolling walker provided post-joint replacement is no longer sufficient to meet the patient's needs. Per Physical therapy recommendation, the patient now requires a U-step neurological walker to support their mobility and safety in light of this altered condition. We kindly request a reassessment of the insurance coverage for the updated medical equipment to facilitate the patient's ongoing recovery and well-being. 

Physician Signature                Date

I certify that the durable medical equipment (DME) prescribed above is medically necessary for the treatment of the patient's condition. The specific features and specifications of the prescribed equipment are essential to address the patient's functional limitations, improve mobility, and enhance overall quality of life. This medical necessity statement is based on a thorough evaluation of the patient's medical history, current health status, and the professional judgment of the prescribing healthcare provider. It is our sincere belief that the recommended DME will contribute significantly to the patient's medical care and well-being.

post_text:
I need your advice. I am contemplating a lot lately to be an independent contractor but I am afraid to fail as I am the breadwinner.  I have a daughter going into College and my husband‚Äôs salary mostly goes to his student debt and expenses. I am afraid to give up my full time job but I am also tired of the high taxes. 

Im still looking into opening up my own business, is LLC or Scorp better? How did you turn your businesses into the full time and how long did it take you? 

Thanks in advance for all the input.

comments.text: There are people here much smarter than I in the business areas, but here's my 2 cents: 1. You still have to pay taxes as a self employed solo practitioner, so be sure to save for that, and 2. Do it.

I started my journey July 2023. Fully uncaged Oct 2023. I mainly see Medicare, but a few private. Figure $110/v for Medicare. Run your numbers. I‚Äôm the bread winner too.  I‚Äôm in PA, so $1000/mo for insurance (family of 5). I‚Äôm seeing 25-30/wk. I‚Äôve built a following over the last 14 years, which helps. If your numbers are close go for it!

full_thread_text:

Im still looking into opening up my own business, is LLC or Scorp better? How did you turn your businesses into the full time and how long did it take you? 

Thanks in advance for all the input.

COMMENT 1: There are people here much smarter than I in the business areas, but here's my 2 cents: 1. You still have to pay taxes as a self employed solo practitioner, so be sure to save for that, and 2. Do it.

COMMENT 2: I started my journey July 2023. Fully uncaged Oct 2023. I mainly see Medicare, but a few private. Figure $110/v for Medicare. Run your numbers. I‚Äôm the bread winner too.  I‚Äôm in PA, so $1000/mo for insurance (family of 5). I‚Äôm seeing 25-30/wk. I‚Äôve built a following over the last 14 years, which helps. If your numbers are close go for it!

Hello all! I got an offer from a start up rehab clinic to be a 1099 OT independent contractor. I‚Äôve started my LLC but kind of clueless what steps to do next. The manager told me that filing under S-corp would save me thousands in taxes. Has anyone done this? Which payroll company do you use? 

Also, I purchased liability insurance from myotinsurance.com - has anyone actually used them? Pros? Cons? 

Anything else I could be aware of/ start researching? 

Thanks rehab community!

comments.text: There are more rules with S Corp. you need to assign officers and you (as owner) don‚Äôt just take owners draw. You need to take some payroll on a Corp. I don‚Äôt know all the rules, but definitely look into it before making decision.

Hey there, I would need a little bit more context to help you out fully. Like which state your in? How you‚Äôd be getting compensated? Are you billing out under your LLC or are they paying you? Did you get a TIN/EIN yet? Did you register for a type 2 NPI? Did you credential with insurance companies yet? 

I‚Äôd be happy to help but need some further clarity. Feel free to DM me, just let me know it‚Äôs in regards to this post since it‚Äôs anonymous.

post_text: Hey I would really like all of your opinions!  I am hearing up to open a brick and mortar location, with PT and sime other services.  There is a location that I am looking at in a small shopping center.  Price is good, but not really a desirable center with a 7/11 and a few other shops.  On the other hand it is very centrally located in the middle of tons of housing, next to my kids school, next to a park where all the kids play baseball and soccer.  Do you think location and reputation will make people look past the rest of the shopping center?  All advice is appreciated!

comments.text: Ask the other tenants how they like being there‚Ä¶. And what their interaction with the landlord has been. Consider also how safe you feel coming and going there by yourself at night. Also look closely at parking. Very closely. That can be a big deal breaker for patients if the parking is sparse, or they have to walk far to get to your suite.
Always remember. Location. Location. Location. Would you be going there or your kids? Parents if you will have therapy?

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey I would really like all of your opinions!  I am hearing up to open a brick and mortar location, with PT and sime other services.  There is a location that I am looking at in a small shopping center.  Price is good, but not really a desirable center with a 7/11 and a few other shops.  On the other hand it is very centrally located in the middle of tons of housing, next to my kids school, next to a park where all the kids play baseball and soccer.  Do you think location and reputation will make people look past the rest of the shopping center?  All advice is appreciated!

COMMENT 1: Ask the other tenants how they like being there‚Ä¶. And what their interaction with the landlord has been. Consider also how safe you feel coming and going there by yourself at night. Also look closely at parking. Very closely. That can be a big deal breaker for patients if the parking is sparse, or they have to walk far to get to your suite.

COMMENT 2: Always remember. Location. Location. Location. Would you be going there or your kids? Parents if you will have therapy?

post_text: LLC to an S corp - I‚Äôve been advised by my CPA that this is the right direction for me. For those of you who bill insurance - did that transition affect interacting with insurance or reimbursement at all?

comments.text:
It's just an election for tax classification, no impact on any other business aspect, ein, etc. You will still be an LLC, electing to be taxed as an scorp. 
It could change the way you pay yourself and owner benefit options, etc.
It‚Äôs the right direction IF you are grossing over a certain amount of revenue each year.

full_thread_text:
POST: LLC to an S corp - I‚Äôve been advised by my CPA that this is the right direction for me. For those of you who bill insurance - did that transition affect interacting with insurance or reimbursement at all?

COMMENT 1: It's just an election for tax classification, no impact on any other business aspect, ein, etc. You will still be an LLC, electing to be taxed as an scorp. 
It could change the way you pay yourself and owner benefit options, etc.

COMMENT 2: It‚Äôs the right direction IF you are grossing over a certain amount of revenue each year.

post_text: I have a question about address for mobile practice:  I‚Äôm planning to set up a business account tomorrow.  My PLLC/EIN and RA is my own address; however, I‚Äôd rather the business mail and location listed on website, etc be a PO Box.  Should I use the PO box address for the bank, or will the physical location be necessary? If I decide to be credentialed later with MC will address on my bank account affect paperwork?‚Ä¶Trying to plan the order of things as I‚Äôm chipping away at my to-do list with limited free time.üòâ

comments.text: My state would not allow the registered address to be a PO box, UPS box, or virtual. Home address was needed and then I was able to indicate a mailing address. Same thing with Medicare
You can have a mailing address with your Medicare application but will need to list your home as the practice location. Home base/administrative office only.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a question about address for mobile practice:  I‚Äôm planning to set up a business account tomorrow.  My PLLC/EIN and RA is my own address; however, I‚Äôd rather the business mail and location listed on website, etc be a PO Box.  Should I use the PO box address for the bank, or will the physical location be necessary? If I decide to be credentialed later with MC will address on my bank account affect paperwork?‚Ä¶Trying to plan the order of things as I‚Äôm chipping away at my to-do list with limited free time.üòâ

COMMENT 1: My state would not allow the registered address to be a PO box, UPS box, or virtual. Home address was needed and then I was able to indicate a mailing address. Same thing with Medicare

COMMENT 2: You can have a mailing address with your Medicare application but will need to list your home as the practice location. Home base/administrative office only.

post_text: I‚Äôm an OT with a solo mobile outpatient practice. If I rent space from a PT in his clinic and continue to operate and function independently under my own LLC and we refer patients to each other will this violate anti kickback statutes?

comments.text: Following up on this post: rather than paying a set monthly rent, we discussed me paying him $x per patient visit to use his facility and equipment so that I‚Äôm not losing money during slow months. So monthly cost would be variable. I‚Äôd be paying that set amount per patient regardless of if the referral came from him or someone else. Thoughts?

Nope. 
Probably the only way you would be in violation would be if you each received compensation for referring the patient to the other.

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm an OT with a solo mobile outpatient practice. If I rent space from a PT in his clinic and continue to operate and function independently under my own LLC and we refer patients to each other will this violate anti kickback statutes?

COMMENT 1: Following up on this post: rather than paying a set monthly rent, we discussed me paying him $x per patient visit to use his facility and equipment so that I‚Äôm not losing money during slow months. So monthly cost would be variable. I‚Äôd be paying that set amount per patient regardless of if the referral came from him or someone else. Thoughts?

COMMENT 2: Nope. 
Probably the only way you would be in violation would be if you each received compensation for referring the patient to the other.

post_text:
For those who run their PT practices out of other businesses like gyms, wellness facilities, chiropractic offices, etc,. what should I expect to pay to rent or lease space on a monthly basis? This would be very part time to begin - less than 15 hours per week. I know this will vary by location, but wanting some averages to go off of for negotiations.

Edited to add: this will be in the Midwest near Kansas City, MO. And a shared space not my own.

comments.text: RE is so location dependent that your best bet is to find out the local per sq foot rate is and go from there.

Another thing to consider is will the space be completely yours? So can you leave marketing materials up in the common area even when you are not there? Or is it a shared space that you will only be renting hourly/as needed? 

I recommend trying to negotiate an hourly rate or fixed lease amount instead of paying a percent of what you are making‚Ä¶ the country club I rent from wanted me to do 70/30 with them but I asked for a fixed amount and they agreed to $650/month. I‚Äôm in California so this was very reasonable. I‚Äôm now making 8-10k a month so I definitely got the better end of the deal by not agreeing to go 70/30

full_thread_text:
POST: For those who run their PT practices out of other businesses like gyms, wellness facilities, chiropractic offices, etc,. what should I expect to pay to rent or lease space on a monthly basis? This would be very part time to begin - less than 15 hours per week. I know this will vary by location, but wanting some averages to go off of for negotiations.

Edited to add: this will be in the Midwest near Kansas City, MO. And a shared space not my own.

COMMENT 1: RE is so location dependent that your best bet is to find out the local per sq foot rate is and go from there.

COMMENT 2: Another thing to consider is will the space be completely yours? So can you leave marketing materials up in the common area even when you are not there? Or is it a shared space that you will only be renting hourly/as needed? 

I recommend trying to negotiate an hourly rate or fixed lease amount instead of paying a percent of what you are making‚Ä¶ the country club I rent from wanted me to do 70/30 with them but I asked for a fixed amount and they agreed to $650/month. I‚Äôm in California so this was very reasonable. I‚Äôm now making 8-10k a month so I definitely got the better end of the deal by not agreeing to go 70/30

post_text: Hi! I opened my LLC in NH and am in process of moving to ME. I will still be treating patients occasionally in NH via the mobile portion of my practice. I am trying to determine what I need to do with my LLC... change it over to ME, keep it in NH, or carry an LLC in both states. Any advice?

comments.text: If you are your own registered agent, your LLC has to move to where your permanent address is and then you‚Äôll file with NH to be a foreign entity.

You will file a ‚Äúforeign‚Äù LLC in the new state that Is based in the old state. 

That‚Äôs what I have had to do for MS and TN.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi! I opened my LLC in NH and am in process of moving to ME. I will still be treating patients occasionally in NH via the mobile portion of my practice. I am trying to determine what I need to do with my LLC... change it over to ME, keep it in NH, or carry an LLC in both states. Any advice?

COMMENT 1: If you are your own registered agent, your LLC has to move to where your permanent address is and then you‚Äôll file with NH to be a foreign entity.

COMMENT 2: You will file a ‚Äúforeign‚Äù LLC in the new state that Is based in the old state. 

That‚Äôs what I have had to do for MS and TN.

post_text: Is anyone a sole proprietor and using DBA instead of LLC? Or even another variant? How do you know which route to go?

comments.text:
You cannot have a DBA without first being some kind of entity. 

**EDITED TO ADD: I was wrong. Apparently you CAN file for just a DBA. Check out Sue Doyle's comment for more.**

For example. I originally filed as an LLC under the name Next Level Movement Physical Therapy and Wellness.

Then, because I was functionally going by this name anyway, I filed for a DBA to use the name Next Level Movement. Same business, same taxes, same everything, just an additional name I can legally go by. 

I have since changed to an S-Corp, and everything is basically the same. My tax number (EIN) and DBA didn‚Äôt change at all.
the DBA does not provide you with the same legal protection as an LLC. Also some states have different requirements for business structures for therapists. Check with your secretary of state website

full_thread_text:
POST: Is anyone a sole proprietor and using DBA instead of LLC? Or even another variant? How do you know which route to go?

COMMENT 1: You cannot have a DBA without first being some kind of entity. 

**EDITED TO ADD: I was wrong. Apparently you CAN file for just a DBA. Check out Sue Doyle's comment for more.**

For example. I originally filed as an LLC under the name Next Level Movement Physical Therapy and Wellness.

Then, because I was functionally going by this name anyway, I filed for a DBA to use the name Next Level Movement. Same business, same taxes, same everything, just an additional name I can legally go by. 

I have since changed to an S-Corp, and everything is basically the same. My tax number (EIN) and DBA didn‚Äôt change at all.

COMMENT 2: the DBA does not provide you with the same legal protection as an LLC. Also some states have different requirements for business structures for therapists. Check with your secretary of state website

post_text:
Looking to change the name of my LLC. Is it easier to: 

1- create a new LLC, get a new EIN, and new bank account then switch over my online courses to this account
2- amend the current LLC name, amend the name with the IRS (EIN), and amend the name on the bank account and keep all my material as is

Considering it took the IRS 2+ months to get my husbands EIN due to naming similarities I am worried they are going to be nice and slow‚Ä¶. Anyone have experience with this and can give their two sense?

comments.text: Yes, do a DBA. Mine took 24 hours (legal zoom messed up my name). You file a form with the state, and then your LLC is ‚ÄúDoing Business As‚Äù the new name. Same EIN and everything. In Montana it was like $10 to change
You could just add a DBA (doing business as) name.

full_thread_text:
POST: Looking to change the name of my LLC. Is it easier to: 

1- create a new LLC, get a new EIN, and new bank account then switch over my online courses to this account
2- amend the current LLC name, amend the name with the IRS (EIN), and amend the name on the bank account and keep all my material as is

Considering it took the IRS 2+ months to get my husbands EIN due to naming similarities I am worried they are going to be nice and slow‚Ä¶. Anyone have experience with this and can give their two sense?

COMMENT 1: Yes, do a DBA. Mine took 24 hours (legal zoom messed up my name). You file a form with the state, and then your LLC is ‚ÄúDoing Business As‚Äù the new name. Same EIN and everything. In Montana it was like $10 to change

COMMENT 2: You could just add a DBA (doing business as) name.
