post_text:
Do you know when everything changed for me in business?

When I stopped reading everything and looking for the secret sauce.

I read over 110 business books when I first started my practice in 2016‚Ä¶

I still made tons of mistakes and had to learn on the fly.

And the most eye-opening part?

I‚Äôve re-read many of those books and ONLY about FIVE of them are actually worth keeping and implementing.

We live in a world where information is almost too abundant. Stop information gathering, and start implementing üëä. You will be thankful you did. üòÉ

comments.text: Yessss ...  stop consuming and start producing.

The RIGHT book at the RIGHT time can help tremendously, so dont hear me completely wrong. I just want to save people from over-consuming. Implementation is the #1 ingredient needed to get a business moving. Ill post the five books later and when they were helpful

post_text:
I had a lymphedema trained therapist approach me wondering if I'd be interested in bringing her on ~10hrs/week but exclusively for lymphedema care. For those of you who do lymphedema, how do supplies get covered? Is that something the patient typically pays for or would I need to partner with a DME supply company and eat that cost out of my margins? She didn't know, apparently that was all handled by back office staff at her last job.

She says her typical practice pattern is 2-3 units of manual 97140 + 1 unit of either TherEx 97110 or self care 97535. Less commonly 97760 for orthotic mgmt. If that's the case she'd pull in ~10-20% less revenue/visit than is typical for our other patient visits and if supplies come out of my margin, I'm not sure it makes financial sense to pursue it.

I bill MCR/MCAID and OON all other payers if that matters.

comments.text:
I have worked in an outpatient setting and now on my own as a lymphedema/oncologist OT. It has always financially made sense for the patient to buy either bandaging supplies or compression garments- it‚Äôs also the psychology of the patient buying into the program. It‚Äôs cheaper for the patients online to order if the therapist helps determine what the patient needs. Like it was said in previous comments, once the Lymphedema Treatment act goes into effect, patients will hopefully have better coverage (commenting period is going on until August 28th).

As for billing, it depends what your current clinic offers and how you bill. What the therapist is proposing her typical billing sounds about right. You definitely won‚Äôt get rich with lymphedema therapy, but check your area because there‚Äôs generally a great need in all communities with too many patients to serve and not enough therapists

Ive worked in a large hospital based clinic for many years. We started with clinic providing supplies but ended up having patients pay for supplies because of cost. We found a DME provider that will order supplies and ship them to patient (we just filled out order form and sent to vendor at eval). Some insurances do cover supplies so this particular provider runs benefits and bills accordingly. 
I've recently started a mobile practice and do not plan to provide supplies because of cost. This may be a barrier because of OOP costs for the patient, however, the lymphedema treatment act goes into effect Jan 2024. At this time, we don't know what will/won't be covered but hopefully it will provide adequate coverage for supplies and garments.

post_text:
Hi all,
I am thinking about potential relocation to Orlando, FL and had a few questions:

1) Do I need to be licensed in the state of FL to apply/open up a business there? Or can I use my current state‚Äôs licensure as proof that I am a Physical Therapist to be able to open a business there? I want to be able to start my business as soon as I get there
2) If I can‚Äôt start my business immediately with a FL registered EIN, can I treat patients under my current business while waiting for my FL business to be finalized?
3) What type of business structure is required for PT/OT clinics in FL? (PLLC, LLC?)

I have been searching away online however I couldn‚Äôt find clear answers to these questions. 

Any leads for people that help you set up your business in FL or can answer questions would be highly appreciated.

Thank you!

comments.text: I believe you will need to take a laws and rules exam to get your license in FL.
Fl you can do LLC. You'll need to be fully licensed IN Florida to treat patients there.

post_text: Brand new business here - Have an opportunity to rent space that is a little smaller than I was hoping for but for a much better price than I can find anywhere else within my area, but landlord wants a minimum of 3 yr lease. My fear is what happens if I outgrow the space before 3 yrs since I feel it is a bit small to start? Since it's a brand new business I don't know if the business will flop or take off so hard to know what to worry about when it comes to size of a space. Anyone been in this situation before? Advice?

comments.text: Negotiate...if you really like the space, but it's on the small side, perhaps you can offer to pay  more/month for say a year commitment, and then options to renew clause at 6 month increments ( with small percentage increases) for example. Doesn't hurt to throw things out there if you haven't already!
Write in a back out clause. We have been in business a long time sign every 5 years.   Our back out is a 6 month notice. No penalty.

full_thread_text:
POST: Brand new business here - Have an opportunity to rent space that is a little smaller than I was hoping for but for a much better price than I can find anywhere else within my area, but landlord wants a minimum of 3 yr lease. My fear is what happens if I outgrow the space before 3 yrs since I feel it is a bit small to start? Since it's a brand new business I don't know if the business will flop or take off so hard to know what to worry about when it comes to size of a space. Anyone been in this situation before? Advice?

COMMENT 1: Negotiate...if you really like the space, but it's on the small side, perhaps you can offer to pay  more/month for say a year commitment, and then options to renew clause at 6 month increments ( with small percentage increases) for example. Doesn't hurt to throw things out there if you haven't already!

COMMENT 2: Write in a back out clause. We have been in business a long time sign every 5 years.   Our back out is a 6 month notice. No penalty.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you that started business in one county and have grown to more counties of operation, what kind of legal setup did you need to do? I have a 100% cash pay, mobile therapy practice in CA if that helps.

COMMENT 1: We set ours up as a second location and had a parent LLC with sub llc's for liability.

Hi all!!

Question for Illinois self employed therapists. From what I have read, I need to start a PLLC but when I went to the website to create, the only option is an LLC. Do I need to start with an LLC and then covert to a PLLC somehow? Thank you!!

comments.text: I don‚Äôt think you can apply online for PLLC. I had to go mail in my application since there‚Äôs no option for LLC online. Then once your articles of organization get accepted through Secretary of State (2-3 weeks later) you have to apply through IDFPR separately. That portion I did all online. Then it took another 6 weeks for my to get my business license after I submitted to IDFPR. It‚Äôs super annoying

post_text:
Quick question about operating an LLC. I‚Äôve owned and operated my speech therapy business since 2020 and am looking to hire my third independent contractor this fall. She asked me an interesting question that I‚Äôm not 100% sure about. She was wondering if it might be a good idea for her as a speech therapist to open her own LLC before coming to work with me at mine so that any personal expenses for therapy materials could be written off as tax deductions. My guess is eventually she will want to have her own speech therapy business and that she will use the experience she gets from working for me as a launching pad for her own practice (which is totally fine). I just wanted to make sure that as the owner of an LLC that I can pay the owner of another LLC as an independent contractor and that this arrangement complies with all relevant laws and regulations ü•¥. 

Thanks for any input!!

comments.text: That would actually be best for both of you! Just make sure she is actually functioning as an IC and not an employee
Ok thank you for that! I just wanted to make sure there wasn‚Äôt some rule against my speech therapy LLC paying her speech therapy LLC for the same services!

My guess is eventually she will want to have her own speech therapy business and that she will use the experience she gets from working for me as a launching pad for her own practice (which is totally fine). I just wanted to make sure that as the owner of an LLC that I can pay the owner of another LLC as an independent contractor and that this arrangement complies with all relevant laws and regulations ü•¥.

post_text: Mobile PT providers: For Part B MCR do they HAVE to be seen in their home location or can they be seen for services at a location of their choice? For instance a gym they belong to, another location other than their specific home if their home isn't conducive for PT and they want to use you as their PT and not go to an actual Clinic, etc....

comments.text: They must be seen in their home for Medicare to cover the service.

Has to be their home or a clinic for Medicare to cover it.

Anywhere else is not a covered service. (Meaning you can charge your cash rate.)

full_thread_text:
POST: Mobile PT providers: For Part B MCR do they HAVE to be seen in their home location or can they be seen for services at a location of their choice? For instance a gym they belong to, another location other than their specific home if their home isn't conducive for PT and they want to use you as their PT and not go to an actual Clinic, etc....

COMMENT 1: They must be seen in their home for Medicare to cover the service.

COMMENT 2: Has to be their home or a clinic for Medicare to cover it.

Anywhere else is not a covered service. (Meaning you can charge your cash rate.)

post_text: California PTs. What are the fees you have to pay with the business entity as a P corp? I‚Äôm trying to see what is worth it for me in terms of doing my own thing in California.

comments.text: You‚Äôll need to pay for P.C. It‚Äôs all on the website. Then you can decide if you want to be an S-Corp or not. It‚Äôs all pretty affordable to start. Investing in yourself is when it can get a little more expensive.

I believe it's still $125 to file the Articles of Incorporation on the secretary of state website. Since we can't have a LLC in CA (see Moscone-Knox Act of 1976), it saves you the $800 LLC fee to incorporate plus the $800 annual LLC tax.

full_thread_text:
POST: California PTs. What are the fees you have to pay with the business entity as a P corp? I‚Äôm trying to see what is worth it for me in terms of doing my own thing in California.

COMMENT 1: You‚Äôll need to pay for P.C. It‚Äôs all on the website. Then you can decide if you want to be an S-Corp or not. It‚Äôs all pretty affordable to start. Investing in yourself is when it can get a little more expensive.

COMMENT 2: I believe it's still $125 to file the Articles of Incorporation on the secretary of state website. Since we can't have a LLC in CA (see Moscone-Knox Act of 1976), it saves you the $800 LLC fee to incorporate plus the $800 annual LLC tax.

post_text: Hi everyone, I have given notice at my corporate job and in the process of creating an LLC to branch off on my own! I have a couple business names in mind, however, when searching online to see if they are available, there are a ton of different websites to check. Does anyone know of a legit website that will allow me to check if the name is available for use? Also, Does the name need to be available in my state (AZ) or nation wide? Thank you for any information!!

comments.text: Like most people here have said definitely check with the state when filing. Then once you have the name and logo try to trademark it or at least run a search before creating a ton of marketing materials.

When you apply for your LLC the site should have an option to see if the name is available in that state or it likely won‚Äôt allow you to create the LLC with that name. That‚Äôs how colorados was. Made life easy

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi everyone, I have given notice at my corporate job and in the process of creating an LLC to branch off on my own! I have a couple business names in mind, however, when searching online to see if they are available, there are a ton of different websites to check. Does anyone know of a legit website that will allow me to check if the name is available for use? Also, Does the name need to be available in my state (AZ) or nation wide? Thank you for any information!!

COMMENT 1: Like most people here have said definitely check with the state when filing. Then once you have the name and logo try to trademark it or at least run a search before creating a ton of marketing materials.

COMMENT 2: When you apply for your LLC the site should have an option to see if the name is available in that state or it likely won‚Äôt allow you to create the LLC with that name. That‚Äôs how colorados was. Made life easy

post_text: If I wanted to do a test and just start out with 1 or 2 clients via cash based services, just to see if its feasible and something I would like to do, what is the absolute minimum I need to get started in the state of NY? I've had a couple people ask I if provide private mobile services and I would like to maybe try it out. Is it possible to get started without formulating a LLC/PLLC?

comments.text:
My Dad did private cash pay patients back in the late 1950s and 1960s. He was a PT at a NYC hospital PT department and then treated some of those patients at their homes when they were discharged. He did this in evenings after the hospital job. He drove many many miles. 
He then branched out into renting or selling them PT equipment, finally setting up an equipment company. 
It‚Äôs absolutely doable. 
Go get ‚Äòem!
DBA is possible but leaves you personally open to liability‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs my understanding in New York

full_thread_text:
POST: If I wanted to do a test and just start out with 1 or 2 clients via cash based services, just to see if its feasible and something I would like to do, what is the absolute minimum I need to get started in the state of NY? I've had a couple people ask I if provide private mobile services and I would like to maybe try it out. Is it possible to get started without formulating a LLC/PLLC?

COMMENT 1: My Dad did private cash pay patients back in the late 1950s and 1960s. He was a PT at a NYC hospital PT department and then treated some of those patients at their homes when they were discharged. He did this in evenings after the hospital job. He drove many many miles. 
He then branched out into renting or selling them PT equipment, finally setting up an equipment company. 
It‚Äôs absolutely doable. 
Go get ‚Äòem!

COMMENT 2: DBA is possible but leaves you personally open to liability‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs my understanding in New York

post_text:
Yoga/Tennis LLC Question: If I am teaching yoga and tennis as an independent contractor through my llc do I need personal or business insurance? I am the only person in my llc but working under other gyms/studios. Also, do I need PT insurance for my license even though I‚Äôm not providing PT services? 

Thanks for your help and input!

comments.text: I would establish yourself as a business entity for tax benefits and for the protection of your personal assets.  You do not need ‚ÄúPT‚Äù insurance if you are clearly not providing therapy
I have berxi and they cover a PT and their ancillary services like personal training.

COMMENT 1: I would establish yourself as a business entity for tax benefits and for the protection of your personal assets.  You do not need ‚ÄúPT‚Äù insurance if you are clearly not providing therapy

post_text: Business owners beware of being contacted by people calling from "merchant services" who say that you have been overcharged credit card processing fees and they will refund you. While they only call themselves "merchant services", they don't know anything about you or your company. They ask you to either open an account on www.businesstrack.com or send them your recent card processing statement. Luckily, I reached out to my card processing company who confirmed this is a scam.

comments.text: Yep!

post_text: Help! I am starting a mobile side business in CA. I just opened an S-Corp as we can‚Äôt do an LLC here. When meeting with my accountant for personal taxes he told me it was crazy to open an S-Corp prior to having 60/80 K in profit and I should just be a sole proprietor. He recommends that I un-incorporate as s-corps are extra steps and expensive in CA. I did the s-corp so my personal assets are protected but he insisted that a good insurance would cover that. This is against any and all recommendations that I have received. Any thoughts/recs??? I am so irritated about the prospect of starting the process over as I am just about ready to start accepting clients! Thank you in advance.

comments.text: Regardless of what your CPA says, you as a PT can establish ONLY an S-Corp in CA. The CPA may not be aware of that

I actually don't think any of the below answers are correct. You don't HAVE to be an s-corp because s-corp is a tax designation entity. It has nothing to do with the structure of your business. Physical Therapy practices cannot be LLCs in California but individuals can elect to be either a sole proprietor or professional corporation. All professional corporations in California are registered as c-corps initially but can file form 2553 to become an s-corp. The benefits of an s-corp is that taxation is passed on to the shareholder (you if you're the only owner of this corporation) instead of being taxed at the corporate level as well. I don't know the full scope of how profit levels might affect how this pans out but I can say from personal experience that it's fine if you have yours designated as an s-corp. But at the end of the day, consult with another trusted CPA if you want sound advice for your specific circumstance.

full_thread_text:

When meeting with my accountant for personal taxes he told me it was crazy to open an S-Corp prior to having 60/80 K in profit and I should just be a sole proprietor. He recommends that I un-incorporate as s-corps are extra steps and expensive in CA. I did the s-corp so my personal assets are protected but he insisted that a good insurance would cover that. This is against any and all recommendations that I have received. Any thoughts/recs??? I am so irritated about the prospect of starting the process over as I am just about ready to start accepting clients! Thank you in advance.

COMMENT 1: Regardless of what your CPA says, you as a PT can establish ONLY an S-Corp in CA. The CPA may not be aware of that

COMMENT 2: I actually don't think any of the below answers are correct. You don't HAVE to be an s-corp because s-corp is a tax designation entity. It has nothing to do with the structure of your business. Physical Therapy practices cannot be LLCs in California but individuals can elect to be either a sole proprietor or professional corporation. All professional corporations in California are registered as c-corps initially but can file form 2553 to become an s-corp. The benefits of an s-corp is that taxation is passed on to the shareholder (you if you're the only owner of this corporation) instead of being taxed at the corporate level as well. I don't know the full scope of how profit levels might affect how this pans out but I can say from personal experience that it's fine if you have yours designated as an s-corp. But at the end of the day, consult with another trusted CPA if you want sound advice for your specific circumstance.

post_text: I am a new business still in the work of building up/starting out. I want to put up some pictures on my FB and Google pages. Where do you get pictures for your business? I think from www, I would need copyright to reuse? I am not able to take pictures of my own at this time due to not having a personal space and plan to work telehealth/ home visits at this time.

comments.text: I use unsplash a lot. There are some great options there.

Pixabay is another resource, and Pexels. Also MorgueFile, and Wikimedia Commons has millions of free photos free to use. 
Check that the photos you use from these are free for Commercial use.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: I use unsplash a lot. There are some great options there.

COMMENT 2: Pixabay is another resource, and Pexels. Also MorgueFile, and Wikimedia Commons has millions of free photos free to use. 
Check that the photos you use from these are free for Commercial use.

post_text: I started my own business and my concern is more about missing something than anything else. I recently learned about unemployment tax after bringing on a payroll company. So‚Ä¶what else do I not know about. There are a lot of steps. But honestly, I get excited to learn the next part.

comments.text: There is a lot of little things...do you have employees yet? When you do don't miss getting work comp insurance (Some new business owners overlook that when they start to hire). If missed the penalties are high.
Do you have a local small business association that you can ask? That helped me a lot, but I still worry the same since I‚Äôm just starting out

full_thread_text:
POST: I started my own business and my concern is more about missing something than anything else. I recently learned about unemployment tax after bringing on a payroll company. So‚Ä¶what else do I not know about. There are a lot of steps. But honestly, I get excited to learn the next part.

COMMENT 1: There is a lot of little things...do you have employees yet? When you do don't miss getting work comp insurance (Some new business owners overlook that when they start to hire). If missed the penalties are high.

COMMENT 2: Do you have a local small business association that you can ask? That helped me a lot, but I still worry the same since I‚Äôm just starting out

post_text:
**How cool would it be to work with us DIRECTLY for the next four weeks to get your business off the ground?**

Guess what! **YOU CAN!**

We get it that many many of you want to "*see what I don't know* *first"* when starting your own practice.

But, let's be real.  

Is that *RRRREEEEAAALLY* a smart way to start a business - especially when your family's livelihood depends on its success??

So many people have fears and doubts about leaving "the safe job" and making something work - something that they've never done before.

Yet, they choose to go at it blindly.

This may seem harsh, but we are just being honest.  We see this ALL. THE. TIME.

*Why not put yourself at ease and have **DIRECT ACCESS** to us for the next four weeks?*

How, you ask?

Simple.

Join us for the UNCAGED Bootcamp that starts tomorrow (Feb 28th)!

Worried that you might not be able to make all of the calls? Never fear!  Those who register for bootcamp will have access to ALL CALL RECORDINGS.... FOREVER!

That means that you can go back and review whenever you need to do so!

**PLUS!!!!!**

We are available to you during the four weeks to answer any questions you have via email!!  

So, YES!  You have DIRECT ACCESS to us for the next four weeks!  

I mean, seriously! You can start your own practice and have us in your pocket to help you?? 

..... *at a ridiculously low price, too!! *

How crazy... and FANTAWESOME is that??!!!!

Comment "**BOOTCAMP**" below and we will get you the details to register!

LET'S FREAKIN GOOOO!!!

comments.text: Just signed up. Super excited!

post_text:
For those of you who started your business while working for another company in some capacity , how do you get around the conflict of interest statement usually found in the companies handbook? 

*** I did not sign a non compete , this clause is in the handbook ***

I currently still work part time 20 hours at an outpatient facility and have a side business that I‚Äôm building but I‚Äôm hesitant to go hard core with my marketing due to the conflict of interest statement in our handbook which states : 

‚Äú@@ employees must not do anything where their personal interests could conflict or reasonably appear to conflict with the interests at ( this company ) . 
For example, it you were to participate in any business opportunity where you might receive personal financial gain apart from your normal wages, you could be in a conflict of interest situation. 

Personal Financial Gain

You should not take any money separate from your normal wages that could affect your decision making
abilities as a @@ emplovee such as:

You or a family member taking money from a company that does business with this company. 

You or a close family member having ownership in a business that competes with this company 

Outside Activities
You should avoid outside work or actions that could could have a bad effect on ( this companies ) reputation in the community
or could conflict with vour duty to (this company)‚Äù 

I‚Äôm probably going to make an appointment with an employment layer. But I‚Äôm curious because I have not heard anyone address this issue when starting up a business . Most people I have listened too actually encourage you work part time or at least PRN while building. 

** also side note PRN with this company is a W2 so handbook rules still apply **

comments.text:
I spoke to my direct supervisor when getting started. My business is mobile and online which is not something my job offered. 

To avoid conflict of interest, I didn‚Äôt speak about my business at work. When I ended up leaving the job and patients asked where I was going, I said I was changing jobs/settings. Some found me online and started working with me on their own. I never told them to
As long as you aren‚Äôt directly marketing to patients at your current job or ‚Äústealing‚Äù employees at your current job i don‚Äôt see a conflict or problem

post_text: Hi! This is my first time posting as I am new to the group. My spouse and I have owned an outpatient PT clinic in Missouri for the last 6 years. Both of us work full time and we have 3 full time DPT‚Äôs and 1 part-time PTA. We are starting to feel that we are pretty glued to our clinic and one of our therapists wants to take more of the managerial role to allow us a little breathing room. My question is how I‚Äôm the world do you go about this? obviously this is different from a corporation, this is our small business. What tasks/education do you start with?

comments.text: Ask the PT who‚Äôs wanting a bigger role? Get them to tell you how they see themselves helping. You can obviously take it or leave it but i think that‚Äôs a great place to start. Plus, it will provide some new motivation for your manager.

Write down a list of tasks/processes you do on a daily, weekly, and monthly basis. Then decide how much of that you want to delegate and compensate for. Fairly simplistic, but it‚Äôs a good place to start.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi! This is my first time posting as I am new to the group. My spouse and I have owned an outpatient PT clinic in Missouri for the last 6 years. Both of us work full time and we have 3 full time DPT‚Äôs and 1 part-time PTA. We are starting to feel that we are pretty glued to our clinic and one of our therapists wants to take more of the managerial role to allow us a little breathing room. My question is how I‚Äôm the world do you go about this? obviously this is different from a corporation, this is our small business. What tasks/education do you start with?

COMMENT 1: Ask the PT who‚Äôs wanting a bigger role? Get them to tell you how they see themselves helping. You can obviously take it or leave it but i think that‚Äôs a great place to start. Plus, it will provide some new motivation for your manager.

COMMENT 2: Write down a list of tasks/processes you do on a daily, weekly, and monthly basis. Then decide how much of that you want to delegate and compensate for. Fairly simplistic, but it‚Äôs a good place to start.

post_text:
This is for all the newbies who are struggling/doubting themselves.

Valuable lesson learned from flag football:
My 9yo is on a flag football team, and he's the youngest and the smallest kid on the team.  He's also one of the fastest and has a ridiculously good throwing arm with great accuracy.  Unfortunately, his coaches won't give him a chance at QB because of his size, and the kid they play at QB isn't accurate enough to throw long passes.  Last game, I watched my son start to give up.  He was sitting on the sideline with tears in his eyes, trying not to cry and visibly sinking in to sadness.  He was avoiding looking at me so that he didn't melt completely in to tears, but at one point he glanced at me and I mouthed "it's ok" and pointed at my heart and back at him.  His coach I think noticed his change in temperment, too, and a few minutes later he was put in on defense.  I can only assume that he was told to rush the quarterback, because as soon as the ball was snapped my son forced him back 10 yards.  The next play, he did it again.  And his entire body changed after that.  He held his head up, he smiled, he started enjoying it again.
After the game, I pulled him aside and said "listen to me.  There are going to be times that you don't get the shot you think you deserve.  And in those times, you'll have 2 choices.  You can give up and stop trying, and that's ok.  You can make that choice.  But if you do that, no one will ever give you that chance again.  Or, you can choose to go back out and prove to the doubters why they should've believed in you in the first place.  And that's what you did today.  You made them see why they have to give you a chance.  Because you're worth it."
Today has been discouraging, and frustrating, and a little teary on my end.  But I've replayed that conversation in my head a few times, and decided to listen to myself.
It's SUPER hard to start a small business, especially when you're competing with 100 other options.  But it's our job to bounce back and prove why we can't be ignored.

comments.text: We have so much to learn from our kids and how we choose to guide them through life. Just know you're being an amazing example in every way, especially having the courage to start and flourish in your own business. I have a 4 and 6 year old and started 2 years ago
Love that! Also, remind the coach that Stetson Bennett didn‚Äôt get a chance to play QB either, and then won Back 2 Back Natties!

post_text:
Looking for advice: working with a client who is 5 weeks post op Achilles tendon repair and cleared for PWB with wedge in boot. Last week when they started PWB they developed shooting and burning pain into their toes that is worse at night and affecting sleeping. Weightbearing doesn‚Äôt cause symptoms, swelling is controlled, minimal pain in Achilles region, however painful palpation spots are along metatarsal heads and toes. 
Any thoughts on causes or treatment options? 
Heat/ice doesn‚Äôt improve pain. I‚Äôve had them add padding to metatarsal region of walking boot but little relief so far.

comments.text: Sounds like some tension along the plantar fascia insertion areas. My boyfriend had an achilles rupture and repair with the same boot with WB and ROM progression. Maybe some gentle massage and stretching of the toes/foot, some gentle toe flexor strengthening as tolerated. Monitor achilles symptoms as you go, but that's where I'd start.

I‚Äôm not an expert just a PT for 35 years. But was it an open repair by any chance is the sural nerve involved ? Could it have been interrupted or impinged in any way.  Does swelling or scar tissue form near the repair that could be invading it ?  Do you know how to do a nerve release or MFR to the area ?

full_thread_text:

Weightbearing doesn‚Äôt cause symptoms, swelling is controlled, minimal pain in Achilles region, however painful palpation spots are along metatarsal heads and toes. 
Any thoughts on causes or treatment options? 
Heat/ice doesn‚Äôt improve pain. I‚Äôve had them add padding to metatarsal region of walking boot but little relief so far.

COMMENT 1: Sounds like some tension along the plantar fascia insertion areas. My boyfriend had an achilles rupture and repair with the same boot with WB and ROM progression. Maybe some gentle massage and stretching of the toes/foot, some gentle toe flexor strengthening as tolerated. Monitor achilles symptoms as you go, but that's where I'd start.

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm not an expert just a PT for 35 years. But was it an open repair by any chance is the sural nerve involved ? Could it have been interrupted or impinged in any way.  Does swelling or scar tissue form near the repair that could be invading it ?  Do you know how to do a nerve release or MFR to the area ?

post_text:
There‚Äôs a local pain clinic that is wanting to start a PT side of their practice.

One of the pain docs is an acquaintance of mine that is a partner there. He called and asked if I would be interested in possibly helping start and join them and be a partner. Not sure of all the exact details yet. But how does one talk about partnership in this situation?

He also mentioned they may be interested in buying my practice and compensating me. Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm interested in this.

But as far as what to say or what to ask, where do I start? Anyone ever been in a similar boat? I Don‚Äôt want to sound naive and not know what I‚Äôm talking about then get the short end of the stick.

The pain doc that called me said that they don‚Äôt know anything about PT or where to even start on how to go about things.

comments.text: If the physician plans to LLC the PT side consult legal issues just to be careful. There can be issues with physician owned clinics where they refer only to ‚Äúthemselves ‚Äú

I was/am in a similar position, although I did not have my own clinic. I was approached by an OBGYNs office to start a pelvic health clinic for them as they also did not know anything about PT and especially not everything we can treat with pelvic PT. I am pretty much an employee, salaried and I own a percentage of the clinic, did not require my own money to purchase. They handle billing, marketing (I develop education for patients and physicians), and referrals. They're building a clinic on the first floor of their office so I was involved in clinic layout and equipment purchasing. Let me know if you have any questions.

post_text:
Prefacing this by saying that I have reached out to multiple lawyers and hopefully have found one that I can officially consult with, but I'd like a bit of background knowledge going into the conversation.

So for those more legally inclined group members (Iris Kimberg)....

I'm getting my ducks in a row to return to the world of cash-PT. I currently own a DE LLC that i had completed concierge visits and remote coaching and consulting for weight loss and personal training through. However since it's creation I have moved to NYS where a PLLC or PC is required to practice. 

 I‚Äôm wondering if I need to establish another separate entity, or if the original entity could DBA another in NYS? I'd rather not have to go through the whole process of building out another website, business banking, social media presence, etc. and would much prefer to merge the original DE LLC and the new professional entity if possible. 

Thanks in advance!

comments.text: Even if you have to create a new LLC your website, social, and banking can all remain the same. For banking you just take in the new docs to the bank. Social has nothing to do with LLC. Website you'll just update your LLC anywhere. I'm not sure if the legalities of ny but I'd imagine you'll need one there.

post_text:
Times have changed significantly since 2016‚Ä¶

That is the year I started my practice - Freedom Physical Therapy.

I remember buying an ebook titled ‚Äú12 things to do to start your practice‚Äù for $50 because I couldn‚Äôt find much information online about what to do. It was similar in nature to the free 10 step checklist we give out in this group, but that‚Äôs all there was at the time ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Now, fast forward to 2023, and we have more information than we know what to do with at our fingertips!

This is GREAT, but it also presents a new problem: information overload. 

Information overload can be paralyzing, in fact, it actually inhibits us in most cases from taking action.

Last year, we saw this problem growing and growing, and decided to launch Uncaged Bootcamp ü•æ. 

We saw the problem of a) new practice owners needed access to the RIGHT information, b) new practice owners needed access to the RIGHT AMOUNT of information, and c) new practice owners needed it at a price that they could afford to get the information and guidance they need.

That‚Äôs why we launched Bootcamp. 

And the first one of the year is kicking off on Tuesday, January 24th!

Myself, Kevin DeGroot, and David Bayliff will be coaching and teaching you how to set up your practice for success over the course of 4 weeks.

If you are interested, comment ‚ÄúBootcamp‚Äù or ü•æ and we will send you the link to get registered!

post_text: Can I get some feedback on my new marketing posts I am working on?

comments.text: I would remove the words, care and right now. Agree with Kimberly, the picture gives the impression the person will get a massage. Lastly, why limit your patient population ? Back pain post work out gives the impression you are seeking young active patients . Geriatric patients could be big clients of yours .

try  "Has your back pain increased since starting your workouts" or ...since you started to workout"

 "I am a mobile physical therapist offering one on one care in your home"

lastly you offer "an hour" not "a" hour

post_text:
I plan on changing our Game room to a treatment/gym area. This is what it currently looks like. I do mostly ortho, looking to maybe cert in TPI, live in big golfing area. Any thought on what basic initial equipment I should start with ? The rehab hospital that I currently work for will be selling out all of their equipment.

Hx: After 23 yrs working in a OPPT hospital owned practice finally want to move toward my true goal of cash based private practice. The more I learn the more I realize how much more I need to learn! A bit nervous üò¨

comments.text: If you're going to target golfers, I'd invest in a GoPro or camera that could be set-up to record their swing so you can identify areas of tightness/weakness/pain to work on. A treatment table and perhaps Swedish Ladder for stretching, anchoring resistance bands, etc. I'm always a fan of large mirrors so patients can actually see what I'm talking about when dissecting their movement patterns. It's tempting when there's a sale nearby, but I prefer the less-is-more approach. Perhaps if they are getting rid of a wall-mounted stretching ladder or resistance band "system" and plinth, that'd be a great start. Good luck on your endeavor!

The best advice I can give is just take the first step and don't stop you'll never know enough to do it right.  You'll learn and get better along the way.  The first step is ALWAYS the hardest part.  Get the basic things you need and get started NOW!

post_text:
Questions for starting a mobile practice! Just getting started (not seeing patients yet, just getting biz side organized) and new to all this, sorry if these are repetitive, have searched multiple groups and am looking for some more clear answers than what I have found. TIA! :D
1. DBA vs LLC? Was recommended by an attorney and an accountant to start with just DBA to reduce initial overhead and annual costs until I have a steady revenue stream. Pros/cons of either? I have looked into this extensively but having a hard time finding specifics aside from the liability and assets. I also read that my SSN would be put on superbills if I did not set up an LLC with a separate EIN? Is this true or are there ways around putting your SSN on superbills?
1. Direct access limitations: if there is a limitation on how long we can treat (90 day direct access), how do you contact physician at end of 90 days? With a plan of care and get their signature? Does this mean that whatever EMR system I choose should be set-up to fax? I was going with Jane App but saw that someone said they aren't set up to fax?
1. Do I need to go into Proview and update all my personal information, license renewel, etc? It was previously filled out by my former employer. Is this only if I plan to accept insurance (I don't)? 
1. NPI type I or II? I plan to be strictly cash based with option to provide superbill.
1. Is business coaching worth it? I know I probably need it, but I ended up having to quit my job because my childcare fell through, so I do not currently have a reliable paycheck and want to keep costs low. Are their any coaching or mentorship programs that are less than $1000 that people have found worth it? Thank you all so much!!

comments.text: LLC will protect your personal assets. It separates your personal from business and it doesn‚Äôt cost much to do vs liability.
In MI a DBA is under an LLC?

post_text: So I‚Äôm in California and I went ahead and filed for a S Corp however IncFile stated that I need a professional corporation instead. I thought all I needed was a s corp, receive the EIN number for a business bank account, and obtain a type 2 NPI number for super bills.

comments.text: Hi Wayne , so I. California you need PLLC with sub SCorp

It is my understanding that we need a PC in CA, then file as an S Corp. When I filed in 2018, PTs couldn‚Äôt file as PLLC, so depends on your profession‚Ä¶and of course regulations could have changed since 2018!

full_thread_text:
POST: So I‚Äôm in California and I went ahead and filed for a S Corp however IncFile stated that I need a professional corporation instead. I thought all I needed was a s corp, receive the EIN number for a business bank account, and obtain a type 2 NPI number for super bills.

COMMENT 1: Hi Wayne , so I. California you need PLLC with sub SCorp

COMMENT 2: It is my understanding that we need a PC in CA, then file as an S Corp. When I filed in 2018, PTs couldn‚Äôt file as PLLC, so depends on your profession‚Ä¶and of course regulations could have changed since 2018!

post_text: I have a tax question. I have an LLC. I was told to file as an S-corp to maximize the tax benefit. Does anyone have any insight on this issue?

comments.text: Just met with accountant and learned a lot about this. Kicker is you must do payroll and have to pay yourself a ‚Äúreasonable wage‚Äù. have to be much more tedious with book-keeping. If you file as S-corp, can‚Äôt go ‚Äúbackwards‚Äù to LLC but as LLC you can change to S-corp at anytime. As a newbie, I‚Äôm gonna stay LLC to keep it simple but if I ever have employees, will likely change to S-corp.

I was told that too everyone does that though wen they first start out u can always change it next year but supposedly more tax breaks and benefits... if u make under 40k a year they say it's better to be an LLC though

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a tax question. I have an LLC. I was told to file as an S-corp to maximize the tax benefit. Does anyone have any insight on this issue?

COMMENT 1: Just met with accountant and learned a lot about this. Kicker is you must do payroll and have to pay yourself a ‚Äúreasonable wage‚Äù. have to be much more tedious with book-keeping. If you file as S-corp, can‚Äôt go ‚Äúbackwards‚Äù to LLC but as LLC you can change to S-corp at anytime. As a newbie, I‚Äôm gonna stay LLC to keep it simple but if I ever have employees, will likely change to S-corp.

COMMENT 2: I was told that too everyone does that though wen they first start out u can always change it next year but supposedly more tax breaks and benefits... if u make under 40k a year they say it's better to be an LLC though

post_text: I put in my notice today to go PRN at my current company!! Also planning to go PRN with two other agencies just to have flexibility and ensure that I can stay as full as I want/need, but I‚Äôm so thrilled that this gives me the freedom I need to ramp up my own new business! I have three patients ready to start in January, and now I‚Äôll have even more time for marketing and networking! I‚Äôve never worked anything other than full-time for someone else, so this will be a big adjustment for me, but I‚Äôm so excited to make this change! ü•≥

comments.text: You‚Äôve got this.  There are new and different stressors about being your own boss.  But I could never imagine going back to work for somebody else.  It‚Äôs totally worth it!

post_text:
Hey everyone, who is seeing patients in your own home? How is your setup?

Debating home visits, versus my home versus a lease, at least to get started.

TIA

comments.text: If you are seeing Medicare they will do a site visit.  Everything has to be up to snuff there.
You really need to look at your local zoning and home owners association rules (if you have one). Often a small shared professional office might be a way to go.

TIA

COMMENT 1: If you are seeing Medicare they will do a site visit.  Everything has to be up to snuff there.

post_text:
Hey all. Anyone willing to chat about getting their home zoned to start seeing patients out of an office space/garage? I'm trying to keep overhead costs down as I get started. Just got off the phone with my town and they'll need me to apply with my business plan, expected patients/day/hr, etc. and from there go through zoning dept. 

Super new to this and definitely feeling slightly silly as I had no idea this was part of the process to practice out of your homeüòÖ I only anticipate seeing around 5 patients/week MAYBE to start and planned to sublease space at some point from there. TIA!

comments.text:
How much are you going to spend anyways in renovation etc? And how much are the usual commercial rent? Are you in a high traffic area? Are you comfortable seeing people and bringing them to your home? 

Always think with the end in mind. I know we want to save and start slow and low. Go around your neighborhood and look for commercial establishment that does build to suite. That's how I started mine. I got our clinic started without spending a dime. Well, of course a little bit. But you know what im talking about. I got free rent. They have me a budget of 40-50k for construction etc. Good luck and you got this!

Look into your zoning laws and structure your business to coincide with the laws ‚Ä¶ for example ‚Ä¶ one client at a time (not group therapy) for example, our area approves of one client at a time so that multiple cars are not in your neighborhood at one time.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey all. Anyone willing to chat about getting their home zoned to start seeing patients out of an office space/garage? I'm trying to keep overhead costs down as I get started. Just got off the phone with my town and they'll need me to apply with my business plan, expected patients/day/hr, etc. and from there go through zoning dept. 

Super new to this and definitely feeling slightly silly as I had no idea this was part of the process to practice out of your homeüòÖ I only anticipate seeing around 5 patients/week MAYBE to start and planned to sublease space at some point from there. TIA!

COMMENT 1: How much are you going to spend anyways in renovation etc? And how much are the usual commercial rent? Are you in a high traffic area? Are you comfortable seeing people and bringing them to your home? 

Always think with the end in mind. I know we want to save and start slow and low. Go around your neighborhood and look for commercial establishment that does build to suite. That's how I started mine. I got our clinic started without spending a dime. Well, of course a little bit. But you know what im talking about. I got free rent. They have me a budget of 40-50k for construction etc. Good luck and you got this!

COMMENT 2: Look into your zoning laws and structure your business to coincide with the laws ‚Ä¶ for example ‚Ä¶ one client at a time (not group therapy) for example, our area approves of one client at a time so that multiple cars are not in your neighborhood at one time.

It's Friday's KICK IT UP A NOTCH... on Saturday! üï∫

I promised my wife yesterday that I would not do any work, and that I would spend the day helping her to decorate the house. üéÑ

It was a great day of actively chillin.

But, I still want to make sure that those who KICKED IT UP this past week got some kudos!

First, WELCOME to all of the new members here in UNCAGED! üëã

Speaking of babies, Kelly Hogan and her wife, Tanya, announced that they are due in May, 2023!!! WOO! HOO! ü•≥

Speaking of new places, Dave Reed is about to open the new location for ORIGIN REHABILITATION!! CONGRATS!! ü•≥

Sometimes its the family members who KICK IT UP A NOTCH.  Massive shout out to David Stiasny, brother-in -law of Irina Stiasny.  He appeared on the tv game show, JEOPARDY!! ü§©

MOUNTAIN WELLNESS, owned by UNCAGED Mastermind member, Charlotte Walters, is adding a new location to her practice.  She is adding BROKEN BAR GYM (Asheville, NC area) as one of her locations!! CONGRATS!! ü•≥

Cale Alexander grew his Famousity a bit.  He had a story written about him and his practice in the local magazine, CanvasRebel!  SOLID, BRO!! üí™

Speaking of Famousity, Tugg Kargbo spoke at the RPHS Varsity Football team dinner!  #impactingkidslives üëäüôå

Duane Scotti crushed another 13.1 in Queens, NY. WAY TO GO, BRO! üí™

Speaking of 13.1, Jaime Pierson ssssmashed her first half marathon in Gilbert, AZ!! BAMTASTIC!! üëä

SOOOO EXCITED for Danielle T. Ochieng and Paul Ochieng!! They got MARRIED!!!! LLLLOVE IT!!! üòçüòçüòç

Naz Nodehi Kicked her Famousity up.  She was featured in @Voyagetampamag!!  HECK YEAH!! ü§©

Kicking it up on the Pickleball court was Spencer Lee.  He won his first gold medal at the PPA Takeya Showcase in Newport Beach, CA!! S O L I D!!! ü•áüëä  (as a former competitive tennis player, I know how much this means!!)

CRUSHING the fitness game were Skye Harry and her man, Martin Bui.  They competed in their first Spartan Race!! üí™

Ready to kick life up a notch is Ciara Morgan.  She got engaged to her guy, Jake!! CONGRATS!!!! üòç

If you are into CrossFit, you know... Mad props to Sydney Vanlandingham who accomplished her first muscleup!! üëäüí™

Sometimes the entire family kicks it up a notch - or, a belt!  Way to go Jing Ruder and your whole family!! They all take taekwondo together, and all tested to elevate their belts!! ü•≥üëä

Kicking LIFE up a notch was Jessica Wright.  She and Sam brought Osmond "Ozzie" James Fatoorehchi into the world!! CONGRATS!!! ü•≥üòç

No doubt that there were many more amazing stories that happened this past week!  GOOD ON YA!! üëäüí™

post_text:
Hi everyone!
I have a question about starting a wellness/fitness service (that does NOT offer PT services) while holding a PT license.
What do I need to do to cover myself in terms of liability? Also, I'm in CA.... What's the deal with LLCs? Do I need to do something else to formally start a coaching business?

More details: after many years of thinking about it (and getting amazing inspiration from this group!) I've decided to take the leap and start a coaching service that focuses on fitness/wellness/mindfulness, is cash based, and not through the healthcare system (not treating injuries, illness, no MD referrals, or taking insurance)
In the meantime I'm still working in acute care (in the ICU and with transplants- completely different vibe üòÖ) and will continue for the foreseeable future.
 Over the past couple years I became a certified health coach, and have taken courses in nutrition, strength training, cardiovascular fitness and mindfulness (in addition to all the coursework I did in undergrad and grad school that applies to wellness). I feel like I'm qualified (maybe over qualified!) to provide coaching services but for some reason I'm terrified to start.

I just want to make sure I don't get in trouble with the PT board or into liability issues just because I hold a PT license... From this page, I see some of you provide wellness/non PT services that are separate from your PT practice. I need your wisdom! üôè 

Thank you for reading this far and for your time! Again, this community has been a huge inspiration, I've been "lurking" for years but too afraid to jump into the conversation until now. Hello, finally!! üôãüèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è‚ò∫Ô∏è

comments.text: I don‚Äôt know the laws in CA, but I could pretty much guarantee there are people with way less qualifications providing the service you‚Äôre describing. You‚Äôll always be a PT, but as long as you aren‚Äôt performing PT I think you‚Äôre probably good to go. Of course, if I‚Äôm wrong, someone please correct me!

You must establish yourself as a legal business entity in your state.  Your Secretary of State determines this and the info is usually on their website or call them.  Then you need to be aware of local and county business laws.  Then ask your CPA which business entity is best for your business goals.

post_text: Does anyone here work within a wellness co-op? Seeking advice on legalities and how well it's worked or not for you. For specifics,   myself (pelvic PT), pediatric OT, lactation consultant, and birth photographer are wanting to get a space together. We'd all run out separate businesses within the same building.

comments.text:
I share an office with a lactation consultant, we are two separate business entities. We both signed a lease together, but when we were hunting some management companies preferred one person signed the lease and the other could be a legal subletter. Some of it might depend how you guys want to set it up, vs how management companies want you to do it. Obviously there are only 2 of us, which is a very different circumstance than 4 of you! We didn‚Äôt go further with anything written (she happens to be a family member) but I would consider some other legal draft between the four of you that wouldn‚Äôt be included in a lease signing. In terms of splitting utilities, cleaning, etc, heaven forbid one relationship goes south or they can‚Äôt make a payment etc. 
Beyond that, we love the set up! Great to have as an easy referral network üôÇ
This sounds like my dream come true.

post_text:
Distraction- the first of the great killers of your business. 

There's an amazing phenomenon that happens as you start to see opportunity around you. Similar to how you start to see the car you want to buy all over, opportunity starts to show up all over the place as well. 

As a staff PT, there's no reason to see opportunity so we often close off our minds to the possibility that there are opportunities outside the traditional staff PT position. 

More and more people are starting to see that this isn't the only option and that they can become "UNCAGED." Then they start a practice and hear all the different things that everyone in this and other groups are doing and there's a level of FOMO that happens that makes us think that we need to pursue every opportunity around us. 

One of the most important things that you can do as a business owner is figure out what's working, find the opportunity (not generally the opportunities) that you want to pursue and then focus and be engaged in that and not let yourself get distracted. 

People often think coaching is only for people who need help figuring out opportunities and strategy but one of the less valued but extremely important aspects of a coach is to help keep you focused on what's the most important.

comments.text: SO TRUE!! Many recognize that the greatest value in having a coach is to keep them focused! üôå

post_text:
Don't know who needs to hear this but as a reminder, your business should work for you not the other way around. 

We use the wrong metrics to determine whether we're  successful. revenue each month, new clients, profit, etc. 

These are all focused on the business as the primary focus for growth and success as opposed to the business owner and members of the organization as the primary focus. 

I believe that most KPIs are helpful and obviously you need to have an understanding of them to know if your business is actually sustainable financially but if we're stopping here we fail to recognize what matters the most. 

Let's see some focus on KPIs of personal growth, health, lack of anxiety, peace of mind, and general joy and fulfillment in our businesses.

comments.text: So true Kevin! Since starting my own business this year I have been able to focus on my own health and stress levels. I have dropped 35# so far and my goal for the calendar year is 50#. Plan on crushing that! Hitting my Kory Personal Indicators- the new KPI üòÑ

So much yes to this!!!! Here are some great changes I have seen in myself since becoming uncaged ( well even before being fully uncaged but starting the process) 
1.  Feeling fire again to learn and be the best PT I can be. 
2. Better sleep 
3. More energy 
4. Improved time allowing for self care which has resulted in 26lbs of weight loss 
5. Boosted self confidence 
6. Allowing myself the opportunity/giving myself permission to dream again‚Ä¶ and then go for it. 

So many great things!

post_text: I‚Äôm considering starting out as a sole proprietor. For those of you who did, at what point did you decide to convert over to an LLC?

comments.text:
The LLC is there to limit your liability and protect you personally. There are different designations for an LLC, such as a sole proprietor, s-corp, and c-corp.

What you may be asking is about when to change to and s-corp or c-corp for tax purposes based on your business.

Hope this helps.

What Paul said above. I did it immediately to limit liability not so much for tax purposes as I was a single member LLC and that's a disregarded entity for taxes (rolls right into personal). SCorp classification of LLC is useful after a certain revenue is hit

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm considering starting out as a sole proprietor. For those of you who did, at what point did you decide to convert over to an LLC?

COMMENT 1: The LLC is there to limit your liability and protect you personally. There are different designations for an LLC, such as a sole proprietor, s-corp, and c-corp.

What you may be asking is about when to change to and s-corp or c-corp for tax purposes based on your business.

Hope this helps.

COMMENT 2: What Paul said above. I did it immediately to limit liability not so much for tax purposes as I was a single member LLC and that's a disregarded entity for taxes (rolls right into personal). SCorp classification of LLC is useful after a certain revenue is hit

post_text: It seems most everyone transitions from mobile to brick and mortar if starting out as a side hustle. After going brick and mortar, does anyone actually prefer mobile? I've seen it mentioned before that brick and mortar gives you more credibility and access to equipment if in a fitness studio, commercial, CF gym etc.

comments.text: The answer is it depends. Are you building a business or are you building your own caseload? I started with mobile and now have brick and mortar. If I had the money before. I wish I started sooner. If it's just me making money, I would stick with mobile. I really wanted to scale and create systems and business so we opened up a brick and mortar. I guess what im going to is, what is really your goal? Regardless, you still win my friend. You got this!

post_text:
So I thought I had the beginning figured out, I went through Bootcamp and my last day at my fulltime job was July 1.

2 days ago, I applied for my LLC registration which ended up getting cancelled because I used the wording, physical therapy and wellness. Incfile.com said those words require me to file a pllc in Texas. Fine... but most online platforms don't do pllcs. I found one called mycorporation.com but I have no idea if this is reputable.  Similar cost structure to Legal zoom, etc. $100 for the basics plus extra for EIN, business licenses, annual reports. (Are these things hard to do yourself?) Versus $900 through the lawyer I contacted. I don't know what else I need... are their business licenses I need other than my own license and EIN? I'm doubting my own common sense and feeling stupid and indecisive.  I just want to get started legally, safely.

comments.text: Go to your Secretary of State website and do it yourself. Super easy
Do it yourself, file directly with state. Also stop paying biz coaches. There are great free resources out there

post_text:
OK. I come here as a scared and nervous dog with my tail between my legs. I know I keep getting told to build relations to get my side hustle, cash practice moving. But HOW?!? 
I have been a "loner" my whole life and am so incredibly introverted. Like to the point a cabin in the woods is my dream. 
I am still trying to work the boots on the ground approach, and literally my anxiety gets so high I feel nauseous. I start shaking. It becomes hard to unbuckle my seat belt. I don't go places regularly and don't have many friends. So my connections are minimal at best. 
How does one get past this phobia of talking to people? How do I start to put myself out there? How do I start to build relations with businesses and others to get referrals? 
Thanks for any input.

comments.text: This has been hard for me too! Although I am not an introvert, but I think there is some level of anxiety for everyone! Something that helped me is reaching out to local business email or social media. Then that gives me a foot in the door and I just say "hi I'm a local business new to the area (*describe a little about yourself/business*, I love how your business does *xyz* and I can really see how we could be a great referral source for each other. Would you have any time to meet in the next 2-3 weeks for me to take you out for coffee and hear more about you and your business?" It works pretty well for me, most people either respond... or ignore me lol No one has ever been nasty... and I live in Jersey lol It gets easier with practice üôÇ you got this!

Start by committing to get there and take the seatbelt off.  Make that commitment.  Get dressed, drive there, and take you seatbelt off.  once you find yourself there it will be easier to talk yourself into the rest.  mini steps that put you in a position where it's ia almost silly to stop there.

The unofficial start to summer. üòé ‚òÄÔ∏è üèñ 

A day that we pause and remember those who gave their lives and their freedom so that we may have ours. üôè

We recognize those who currently serve for their bravery üôå

It is also one of six days during the year that we look forward to because we get to have those days off!

Or, we hope to be lucky enough to get to have them off.

With the weather getting nice, today would definitely be one we would love to be able to spend it with our family and friends.

However, those days off are not always guaranteed. 

Question ‚òùÔ∏è

Are you finding yourself looking forward to those six days out of the year when you can finally take a break - aside from the two weeks that you take off?

Do you feel defeated when you aren‚Äôt the one lucky enough to stay home and chill? üòñ

Everyone else is enjoying the pool, a mid-day BBQ, playing cornhole or tossing the baseball ‚öæÔ∏è around.

Except you.

And you‚Äôre thinking ‚ÄúI just want to be home with my kids!‚Äù

Exactly NINE YEARS AGO TODAY!

Why did I start it?

For days like today.

I hated watching the calendar üóì and counting down the days until I could get that one extra day off.  

Now, I‚Äôm in control.  

My days off aren‚Äôt determined by government appointed Mondays. 

And, by NO means, am I minimizing the meanings of these days like today - Memorial Day üá∫üá∏üôè

‚ÄúFailure is failing to try‚Äù

post_text:
We need to take into account that great achievement involves great risk.

It pains me to see so many people with such incredible dreams ‚Äî impactful, game-changing, earth-shattering dreams ‚Äî then to see that there is an unwillingness to take ANY risk to go after that dream. 

It breaks my heart. Because those dreams‚Ä¶where did they come from? What if that is your true calling in life?

What pains me is people who are not willing to take the risk but then you ARE willing to spend everyday questioning whether or not you are actually living up to your full potential. That‚Äôs not living, that‚Äôs living in agony. 

Our callings don‚Äôt leave us. They will always stay at our proverbial ‚Äúhouse‚Äù, and continue to knock at the door just waiting to be let in.

Some of us aren‚Äôt even willing to open the door. To take a risk in any way. But we all know deep down inside that the only way to make that dream happen is by taking a risk and believing in yourself. 

Open the door. üö™

post_text:
How long it takes to be approved as Medicare B provider for home PT in New York ‚Ä¶
Can I see Med B patient if my application is still in process for Med B credentials ‚Ä¶
Please assist..
TIA

comments.text:
When I started, 3 years ago, it was about 3 months (but there were back and forth due to errors); this month I applied for an 855I for one staff, it only took me less than 1 month. 

I believe there's a window of how many days back that you can bill (that I'm not sure). But I waited until I was enrolled before I started seeing patients.

All the best!

full_thread_text:
POST: How long it takes to be approved as Medicare B provider for home PT in New York ‚Ä¶
Can I see Med B patient if my application is still in process for Med B credentials ‚Ä¶
Please assist..
TIA

COMMENT 1: When I started, 3 years ago, it was about 3 months (but there were back and forth due to errors); this month I applied for an 855I for one staff, it only took me less than 1 month. 

I believe there's a window of how many days back that you can bill (that I'm not sure). But I waited until I was enrolled before I started seeing patients.

All the best!

post_text:
What‚Äôs up everyone. I am relatively new in the group. Don‚Äôt comment much/post but really value everyone‚Äôs expertise and following everyone‚Äôs stories.

I am in beginning stages of my side hustle. Still work full time for an outpatient hospital based system. Got my LLC and am currently operating out of my home. Have 1 client at this time. Goal is to work up to 4-5hrs/week starting out and scale from there.

Reason I was reaching out to everyone is I am meeting with a local gym owner this Friday about possibly renting some space there. Does anyone currently practice out of a gym setting and if so do you have any recommendations/insight on the process of negotiating. I‚Äôve watched some videos/podcasts but was interested in hearing from you all and if you don‚Äôt mind sharing what you paid starting out especially if you didn‚Äôt have much clientele built up. 

Price/month, /patient, etc. or whatever you did.

Thanks so much! Any and all feedback would be appreciated very much! Have a great day!

comments.text:
Hey Joe! I practiced out of a gym for a while, ended up shifting to another location because the accessibility/parking at that gym really limited patient's ability to get there. A few things I'd recommend...if you're keeping your volume small for a while like you mentioned, commission-based pricing is okay but in the long term you want a fixed rate. Even $10/patient may seem small but if you're up to 30 patients a week suddenly you're paying $1200/month so that will backfire unless you make it clear from the get go that you'll do commission short-erm up until you start seeing X patients then switch to a monthly fee. Remember that you're a big asset to the gym...you are helping them be more marketable and that should reflect in a relatively low rent - I paid $700/month which included full access to the equipment and a private treatment room. They also gave me the first 2 months free to get myself set up and get clientele in the door which was a massive help.

Make sure there is adequate parking and it's easy to get to. Due to my experience, that would be a deal breaker for me.

Do workshops at the gym. Volunteer your time 1 night a week (or charge a small fee for the workshop, either way) while you're getting going...present on things they want to hear...how to improve your overhead stability...how to lift and strengthen your back...how to improve X mobility for X lifts...how to strengthen your rotator cuff to avoid shoulder pain etc etc etc...
